story:
Melaku Belay and Fendika's Ethiocolor at 2014 Roskilde Festival

FENDIKA = ETHIOPIA'S CULTURAL IDENTITY

Ethiopia is an ancient country - and at the same time, it is very young: only a short time ago the military government of the "Derg" collapsed and the country could slowly begin to rebuild itself. And only today, a new generation of Ethiopians begins to feel that once again, their country has a cultural identity. 

For two decades now, Melaku and his "Azmari Family" of artists have been essential for this process of rebuilding and reconstitution. Their "home" is FENDIKA, the oldest and most important cultural club in Addis Ababa. If FENDIKA disappears, they will disappear.  

Your contribution to our campaign will allow FENDIKA, Melaku and his "Azmari Family" to continue to exist and contribute to the rebuilding of Ethiopia's cultural identity. Together with Melaku we strongly believe that culture is an essential building part for the national identity of a people. With your donation, you help to continue doing this. 


WHAT CHANGED SINCE THE 1st IGG CAMPAIGN

Back in September, our first campaign here on IndieGoGo to SAVE FENDIKA was a huge success: with the more than 20.000 Dollars we raised, Melaku Belay, owner of the FENDIKA cultural club was able to make a down payment to the owner of the land the club is built on. The property was not sold to a foreign company - instead Melaku got the option to buy it himself.

Now he needs to complete the payment and to fulfill his agreement to purchase FENDIKA. Once again, Melaku and his "Azmari family" of dancers, musicians and cultural operators are asking their friends around the world for help. And this is the final call.

To finish paying for the land and keep FENDIKA safe once and for all, until Christmas Melaku must find the remaining money and pay off the owner. Friends, cultural investors, private money and  the September INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN helped getting closer to that goal. But even with all that support, of the 75.000 Dollars Melaku needs, less than half of this amount has been collected until today. 

If we are all together we will get there and with this campaign manage to bring Fendika under Melaku’s ownership. Finally, Melaku will be able to begin his long-coveted plan for a vibrant new cultural center in Ethiopia's capital Addis Ababa (see the Dec 11 update for details).


Fendika's neon sign on a performance night
 

MELAKU BELAY AND FENDIKA 

This campaign's key video is an extract from our recently completed documentary JAMMING ADDIS, of which Melaku is one of the protagonists. If you haven't watched it yet, do it now: in the clip Melaku speaks about FENDIKA, the Azmari (Ethiopian artists similar to traveling minstrels, more about this below) and the cultural life in his country.  And in the final part of the clip he tells his personal story - which as you will see is quite astonishing.

If you followed the September campaign and know all about Melaku, FENDIKA and Ethiocolor, you can scroll down to the section SO WHAT'S THE PROBLEM? Otherwise, keep reading and watching the other video clips below !

This next clip though is from Melaku's private archives and shows a recent performance at FENDIKA.

(Melaku and his group Ethiocolor at FENDIKA - video courtesy of Melaku Belay)


WHO IS MELAKU BELAY?

Somebody recently has compared Melaku to "a walking meter of ambient electrical activity, translating the vibes on the street into ecstatic dance moves". Others say he is something like "a walking earthquake".

Melaku in "his" taxi 

Melaku worked his way up from being a street kid to one of the most important cultural operators in Addis Ababa and Ethiopia, and of wide international fame. After a long time sleeping on the streets of Addis, he asked the owners of the FENDIKA if he could sleep there and was given permission. In the coming months he slept behind the bar during the day - at night, he watched performances at the club. "Stealing with his eyes" from their movements, he taught himself how to dance. For nine years, he danced at FENDIKA earning only tips, like all the other Azmaris (musicians, singers etc). And it grew in him that this system had to change, that art is weak if it depends on tips only. 

Melaku worked hard for many years - and today owns the club. Around him, he has created a family of dancers, musicians and performers who are regularly invited to many places around the world, including some of the biggest festivals like Roskilde or Africolor, the Sauti Za Busara Festival in Zanzibar, Africolor Festival and Jazz à la Villette Festival in Paris, TFF Rudolstadt World Music Festival in Germany. Musicians from all around the world visit FENDIKA, including THE EX from Holland, La Tigre Des Platanes, Le Bruit Du Sign and Ukadanz from France, the Imperial Tiger Orchestra from Switzerland and others.   

But the best really is to see the man with your own eyes and begin to feel the joy he emanates. In the next clip from our film you will see how Melaku improvises a dance to the mesmerizing music of pianist Samuel Yirga. Sammy and Melaku are good friends and share a common sentiment for the importance of Ethiopian cultural identity.

(link to this clip on our website)


WHY DOES MELAKU'S WORK MATTER?

In the mid 1970s, Ethiopian Anthropologist Tesfaye Lemma and his partner, American Peace Corps volunteer Charles Sutton traveled Ethiopia, discovering singers and musicians in the remotest areas of the country and brought them to Addis. Via national television for the first time Lemma familiarized astonished Ethiopians with their very own musical traditions. His “Orchestra Ethiopia” of traditional musicians brought Ethiopian music to wide international success and even toured the USA. Tesfaye Lemma's work was essential for Ethiopians becoming more and more conscious about their own heritage and the richness of their own musical culture.

Yohannes Afework, member of "Orchestra Ethiopia" and of Melaku's "Ethiocolor"

Today, many say that Melaku is the rightful bearer of Lemma's artistic and spiritual heritage. Some members of the "Orchestra Ethiopia" who worked with legendary Tesfaye Lemma are still alive, most of them work with Melaku in FENDIKA. Flutist Yohannes Afework is one of the ancient members of the "Orchestra Ethiopia" and  participated in the orchestra's famous tour through the US. During a recent lunch meeting at the Ras Hotel, Yohannes surprised all of us, most of all Melaku himself, with what he had to say:


 (link to this clip on our website)


THE AZMARI'S FUNCTION IN ETHIOPIA

Since the beginning of time, the Azmari have been Ethiopia's artists: singers, musicians or poets. They are story-tellers within the ancient tradition of bardic minstrels, similar to the troubadours in European culture. Azmaris are free thinkers who since the dawn of time were allowed to speak the truth at the king's court even when everybody else shut up.

above and below: rehearsal at FENDIKA

Azmari culture is hundreds if not thousands of years old. But their social function is still the same in contemporary Ethiopia: Azmaris speak about social and political issues, about HIV and culture, or simply about the things that happen in the world.  Within the protection that music and lyrics provide to them, Azmaris can say what nobody else can (or dares to say).


WHAT'S SO SPECIAL ABOUT FENDIKA?

The Azmari's art to wrap the message in music, lyrics, a song or masterfully recited poetry requires talent, practice and a lot of exercise. But for all that dedication, the only means of wages Azmaris can aspire to are tips. The concept of "real pay" for artists does not exists.

Historically this "tipping system" made them depend on the whim of their "masters" and the favor of local rulers. And it is no surprise that most Azmaris are constantly one step away from total insecurity. Or, in Melaku Belay's words: "As an Azmari you have to focus on survival, where to get enough food and a place to sleep. Like this, art becomes weak".

"Tipping" legendary singer Zeritu Getahun during her performance


Azmaris can't show their art where they want: in the past it was the ruler's court, today the venues are reduced to very few places. FENDIKA is such a place, called azmari bet or "House of the Azmari". And, what is almost more important, FENDIKA is the first and until today only venue in Addis that provides the artists with a fair and secure pay, instead of keeping them dependent on being tipped by customers or tourists.

In fact, when Melaku took over FENDIKA almost two decades ago, he immediately established regular stipends for the Azmari. This was unheard of in Addis and Ethiopia, and it meant a revolutionary step forward toward artistic independence and freedom. Hence, FENDIKA is economically balanced: the income generated by selling tickets and beverages are used to pay the artists and the club's maintenance.

As flute player Yohannes Afework says in the previous clip, Melaku is doing a great job in keeping the memory of the older Azmari artists alive: FENDIKA is the only place in Addis where many of them can still find enthusiastic audiences.  The next clip will give you an impressive example: Zeritu Getahun began her career in the 1950s (!) and today, at the age of… (who knows) is a regular guest at FENDIKA. Listen to Melaku introducing her as the voice that an entire generation grew up with, and watch her singing one of her best-known tunes in front of an enchanted crowd.


(link to this clip on our website)

MELAKU'S GROUP ETHIOCOLOR

In 2009, one year after Melaku took over the FENDIKA, he also founded his own group of musicians and called it ETHIOCOLOR. Playing at FENDIKA every second Friday of the month, Ethiocolor is an innovative Ethiopian traditional band consisting of Kirar (a kind of lyre), Bass Kirar, Washint (flute), Kebero (traditional drums) and Massinqo. 

Ethiocolor live in Copenhagen, October 29th, 2014 (courtesy of the Paal Nilssen-Love curated Actionjazz Festival)

“Our goal is not just to assemble traditional musicians and create another folk ensemble. Our vision is to demonstrate that the immense musical heritage of Ethiopia can be performed with a great degree of creativity while still maintaining its identity” says Melaku about Ethiocolor.
Each member of the group has extensive experience in Ethiopia and internationally. Ethiocolor's musicians and dancers have work with traditional music but also with jazz, rock, fusion and hip hop. This gives Ethiocolor's music a special edge. Indeed, since its inception in 2009, word has spread fast for the young group of musicians, dancers and singers. After winning a wide audience in Addis Ababa and Ethiopia, they began traveling the world. 
And Ethiocolor's members do not only perform inside the FENDIKA, as you can see from the images below taken during this year's Epiphany festivities… 


Melaku and members of Ethiocolor during "timket" (Epiphany) 2014 


ALL THIS SUCCESS - SO WHAT'S THE PROBLEM?!?

You're right, this is exactly the question we asked ourselves when we first came to Addis Ababa. And then we started seeing cranes and construction sites everywhere and huge areas where people used to live being prepared for the construction of shopping malls and expensive residential buildings.  Ethiopia is on the brink of becoming a part of the globalized world - but it is not yet. Therefore, some things here are… wild.

Addis Ababa's growing new skyline in 2014

Addis Ababa today is seeing an unprecedented rush on construction. Investors mostly from the Middle East and Asia are buying land for low prices and start building hotels or shopping malls on it. This is especially true for the KASANCHIS neighborhood. Once a peripheral area for the less wealthy and north to the city center, Kasanchis has become one of the most popular areas in the very heart of Addis Ababa. 

A map of the central areas of Addis; Kasanchis begins about in the map's center - the red dot in the upper right half is where FENDIKA is located. If you want to find FENDIKA on GoogleMaps, put "Fendika Azmari Bet" into the search field and you'll find it.

Kasanchis is the home of FENDIKA CULTURAL CLUB since more than 30 years. And Melaku lives nearby. In the past two-three years, the neighborhood is being swamped with many new buildings, and most of those cement monsters have been risen up without any other criteria than fast profit. Even residential spaces often have their windows at only a few inches from the concrete wall of the building next to it.

Addis Ababa's symbol before a skeleton made of concrete


Back in September, our first IndieGoGo campaign SAVE FENDIKA was a huge success: with the more than 20.000 Dollars Melaku was able to make a down payment to the owner of the land FENDIKA is built on. The land was not sold to foreign investors - instead Melaku got the option to buy it himself.   

But now Melaku needs to complete the payment and to fulfill his agreement. Once again, Melaku and his "Azmari family" of dancers, musicians and cultural operators are calling for help upon their friends all around the world - and this is the final call.

To finish paying the land and keep FENDIKA safe once and for all, until mid December Melaku must find the remaining money and pay off the owner. Friends, cultural investors, private money and most of all the September INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN helped getting closer to that goal. But even with all that support, of the 75.000 Dollars Melaku needs, less than half of this amount has been collected until today.

constructions and a sky full of "vultures" - quite symbolic…

  Melaku Belay began to launch his own initiative for FENDIKA through Facebook (see here). However, the country's internet is in "prehistoric" conditions. Access to the world wide web lags, speeds are way below what we were used to in the West in the mid 1990s. Even in Addis Ababa, the country's capital, except from some foreign institutions and embassies the internet is extremely slow. To open a Facebook page, Ethiopians have to wait for several minutes - to upload the 330 MBs of the videoclip that comes with this initiative would take more than a week if you did it from Addis... 
All this is why we want to help Melaku on his quest to safe FENDIKA: we want to enable him and his people - his "Azmari family" - to stay where they are and continue their work. Melaku and FENDIKA are already established as a "cultural hub" that is vital for Addis Ababa and important for the rebuilding if the Ethiopian cultural identity. 

We want Melaku to continue his work, to maintain FENDIKA and to build a cultural center on top of the old club building that he will finally own. We are convinced that the Azmaris need Fendika (to survive). Addis needs Fendika (to have a conscience). Ethiopia needs Fendika (to maintain the memory of the past and connect it with the present). And ultimately, we believe that Africa needs Fendika (to keep up the cultural diversity in one of the continent's most diverse and multi-ethnic countries - they call Ethiopia "little Africa" for a reason). 

Ethiocolor performing in FENDIKA

CAMPAIGN TEAM

So who are we and why do we care? All of us have personal and professional  reasons for being attached to FENDIKA and Melaku.

Dirk van den Berg  is a director/producer with extensive international experience based in Berlin, Germany. Between December 2013 and June 2014, Dirk and his team were in Addis Ababa for several times, filming the documentary JAMMING ADDIS. Melaku Belay almost immediately became one of the film's protagonists. More importantly, they became friends. Dirk learned to admire Melaku's passion for Ethiopian culture, his incredible strength and charismatic will-force in his fight for culture. He shares Melaku's belief that culture is one of the most essential building parts for any national identity.  

Lynne Williamson is a folklorist and the director of the Connecticut Cultural Heritage Arts Program. With experience developing cultural heritage projects in the UK and US, she has been assisting FENDIKA and Melaku with touring in the US, communications and fundraising.


THE PRESS SAYS ABOUT MELAKU…

Melaku has meticulously collected press articles from all over the world on his home page. Here are the most important articles and press clippings, beginning with a New York Times publication from only a few days ago:  

In Ethiopia’s Capital, a Resurgent Jazz Scene (Nov 13, 2014)

Ethiopia has been home to 'Azmari Bets' — taverns featuring sung comedy accompanied by a lyre — for centuries, but what the Ethiocolor Band does at Fendika is quite different. Led by the charismatic Addis-born dancer Melaku Belay, the 13-member group has reimagined traditional Ethiopian culture for the 21st century, combining tribal dances and indigenous instruments with jazz, rock, theater and lots of costume changes. On a recent late night, the crowd that gathered around the dancers — wearing spiky wigs made from the hair of gelada baboons — was invited to show off their skills at the 'eskista', a shoulder-shaking jig.
“I believe tradition is never stuck,” Mr. Belay said. The self-taught dancer, who is 38, had first come to the place where the Ethiocolor Band performed when he was a child living on the street. Mr. Belay said that he’d slept under the bar for seven years, earning his board by working without pay. Many years later he bought Fendika Azmari Bet from its former owners and began to shake up the city’s cultural life. As he put it, “I am the bridge to connect jazz and theater to azmaris.”

NEW YORK TIMES - Where Feet, Beat and Joy All Soar Funkily (12 August 2011)

It was a delight to watch and the rhythmic virtuosity of Melaku was often astounding. He can turn either the upper or the lower body into an electrifying vehicle of rapid pulsation. One dance was all to do with his throwing his feet out before him (as if on hot coals). Sometimes the feet alternated, sometimes he hopped, and on one occasion, while hopping brilliantly, he mimed strumming on the other leg, which he kept stretched out like a guitar.

 BBC folk - Ethiopia (26 February 2010)

Another inspirational individual we met was a man called Melaku Belay. Melaku was a Sudanese refugee. His family was dispersed, and he ended up as an orphan and street kid in Addis Ababa. To survive he danced for tips at a music club, where he asked if he could sleep on floor. He managed to earn enough tips to eventually buy the club - an amazing feat! He is now a world famous dancer, performing with the Ethiopiques, yet he always comes home to dance in his club and invest in the community.

THE REPORTER - Clapping, dancing the night away 

‘Ethiopia’ is a single by the renowned American rock band, the Red Hot Chili Peppers. This single was inspired when one band member visited Ethiopia and on his stay here performed at Fendika, and the energy he felt there inspired the band to do a song entitled ‘Ethiopia’. This energy Red Hot Chili Peppers talks about is the feeling many feel when they come to Fendika located in Kazanchis. The owner of Fendika, Melaku Belay remembers twenty years ago how the Azmari places were famous, where the older generation used to come and the poems they used to give for Azmaris were matured ones. And also ten years ago all the Azmari places were flourishing; now most of the businesses have changed.

Melaku somehow tried to give new meaning to Azmaris, paying the Azmaris, since their livelihoods was totally dependent on rewards from the customers...  

ADDIS RUMBLE - Impromptu Addis 

Melaku Belay is one of the sweetest souls I have ever met. I didn’t know him, but I had watched him dance at his traditional azmari bet‘Fendika’ in Addis (one of the best bars in the world!). He’s also in many video’s dancing with The Ex and with Getatchew Mekuria so I thought it would be great to work with him – to find a way to harness his energy into a very kinetic film – but also to show a bit of his skill at getting the people around him involved.

Melaku dancing with Samuel Yirga at "Mama's Kitchen" 

PERKS

You donate to support FENDIKA and Melaku's work - so we are not spending money on meaningless swag that will collect dust under your bed. However, we plan to offer authentic Ethiopian clothes and jewelry, and we will create videos and music so you can share FENDIKA's cultural adventure. 

Promising you to send you goods and gadgets is impossible right now: you can't send any objects from Ethiopia to other countries without being subject to ludicrously high taxes. An Ethiopian dress that costs 10 Dollars in a Kasanchis shop would cost 80 Dollars in taxes and shipping costs. We think that wasting your donations in this way would be a contradiction in terms.  But: all donations will be noticed, each contribution will be recognized. And yes, you can also donate privately. We are grateful for your support.  

In the pane to the right we have more details on some perks that we know we can promise. Keep in mind that you can contribute also without claiming a perk, and whatever you think is right to give to this campaign.  

Without further ado, here come the perks: 

$10 – A photo of Ethiocolor taken at Fendika, with signatures of all band members and a dedication on your name

$25 -  CD mixtape put together by Melaku: this is actually what everybody who comes to FENDIKA asks Melaku to do. And he won't do it because the treasure of LPs and Singles he has is part of FENDIKA's allure for the audiences. For this campaign, he will make an exception, so expect these CDs to grow value as collector's items over time. 

$50 – A scarf from Addis, like the ones worn by dancers. Or if you want it more "natural", we can try to get you one actually worn by the dancers. 

$75 – Free entrance for life at FENDIKA + the 25$ perk (CD mixtape) 

$100 - Free entrance for life at FENDIKA + the 25$ perk (CD mixtape) + the 50$ perk (a scarf from Addis)  

$200 – a praise song in your honour, created by a real Azmari, recorded and sent to you

$500 – guided tour of Addis given to you by Melaku, including the mythical "MERKATO" area

The Addis "merkato" (from the Italian word for "market") is arguably the largest open-air market area on the entire African continent. The following video shows Melaku's experimental performance at merkato some years back. He literally used the sounds,  rhythms and movements of the market's skilful workers and their materials, transforming them with the use of traditional Ethiopian esktista and guragigna  dance. Melaku called his experiment Ahun, which means "Now": on the one hand this underlines the inspirational moment for Melaku's performance, on the other it  captures the continuous transformation of the huge open-air market (note: there is some text in the beginning, the actual video begins at 1'10''). 


Ahun - Now, Melaku's solo performance in 2011 at the merkato area  
(video courtesy of Zeleman Production Addis Ababa)

THE IMPACT OF THIS CAMPAIGN

Perhaps the "big bang" moment for modern Ethiopian music was in 1924, when a brass-band the Emperor brought from a foreign country became Ethiopia's first official orchestra. Until the 1950s, institutional bands dominated, like the Army, the Police and others. But in the mid 1960s musicians began to fuse Jazz, Soul and Rhythm'n'Blues with the traditional Ethiopian five-note scale and the famous "modes" (remember them all? Tezeta, Bati, Anchihoye and of course Ambassel). Ethiopian music reached its first peak in modern times  that became universally known as 'Swinging Addis'. But when the grim Marxist regime of the 'Derg' took power in 1974, it killed 'Swinging Addis' - like it killed almost everything else. Many were murdered, many escaped, most to America. All cultural life was paralyzed. When the horror finished in 1987, only a few musicians found their way back. It took until the second decade of the 21st century that a new generation of Ethiopians began to fill the void. Melaku is one of the protagonists of this generation.  

Ethiopia is an ancient country - and at the same time, it is very young: it was only thirty years ago that the military government collapsed and the country could slowly begin to rebuild itself. And only today, a new generation of Ethiopians begins to feel that once again, their country has a cultural identity. For two decades now, Melaku and his "Azmari Family" have been essential for this process of rebuilding and reconstitution. If FENDIKA disappears, they will disappear - or at least they will be without a home and a space where to experiment and to create their art.   

Your contribution will allow Melaku, the Azmaris and the FENDIKA to continue to exist. And with that, to continue contributing to rebuild young Ethiopians' identities. Together with Melaku we believe that culture is an essential building part for the national identity of a people. With your donation, you help to continue doing this. 

early morning at Fendika: cleaning after an opening night

 

 OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Any financial contribution is appreciated; even 5 Dollars or Euros help us to reach our goal. And there are many other ways you can help:

   •   Use the IndieGoGo share icons above to distribute our campaign to your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Google+ and whatever other flavor you prefer.
   •   Write about our campaign on your blog, website, or publication. We are happy to provide promotional material, and will in turn share your link on our social media channels.
   •   Start listening to Ethiopian Music and see if it gets you as addicted to pentatonic melodies and African rhythms  as us. And if that is so, talk to your friends about our campaign.

And last but not least - check back often. Updates will  be frequent in the coming weeks.

Addis cranes and a plane leaving at sunset
story_txt:
Melaku Belay and Fendika's Ethiocolor at 2014 Roskilde FestivalFENDIKA = ETHIOPIA'S CULTURAL IDENTITY
Ethiopia is an ancient country - and at the same time, it is very young: only a short time ago the military government of the "Derg" collapsed and the country could slowly begin to rebuild itself. And only today, a new generation of Ethiopians begins to feel that once again, their country has a cultural identity. For two decades now, Melaku and his "Azmari Family" of artists have been essential for this process of rebuilding and reconstitution. Their "home" is FENDIKA, the oldest and most important cultural club in Addis Ababa. If FENDIKA disappears, they will disappear.  
Your contribution to our campaign will allow FENDIKA, Melaku and his "Azmari Family" to continue to exist and contribute to the rebuilding of Ethiopia's cultural identity. Together with Melaku we strongly believe that culture is an essential building part for the national identity of a people. With your donation, you help to continue doing this. WHAT CHANGED SINCE THE 1st IGG CAMPAIGNBack in September, our first campaign here on IndieGoGo to SAVE FENDIKA was a huge success: with the more than 20.000 Dollars we raised, Melaku Belay, owner of the FENDIKA cultural club was able to make a down payment to the owner of the land the club is built on. The property was not sold to a foreign company - instead Melaku got the option to buy it himself.Now he needs to complete the payment and to fulfill his agreement to purchase FENDIKA. Once again, Melaku and his "Azmari family" of dancers, musicians and cultural operators are asking their friends around the world for help. And this is the final call.To finish paying for the land and keep FENDIKA safe once and for all, until Christmas Melaku must find the remaining money and pay off the owner. Friends, cultural investors, private money and  the September INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN helped getting closer to that goal. But even with all that support, of the 75.000 Dollars Melaku needs, less than half of this amount has been collected until today. If we are all together we will get there and with this campaign manage to bring Fendika under Melaku’s ownership. Finally, Melaku will be able to begin his long-coveted plan for a vibrant new cultural center in Ethiopia's capital Addis Ababa (see the Dec 11 update for details).




Fendika's neon sign on a performance night
 
MELAKU BELAY AND FENDIKA 


This campaign's key video is an extract from our recently completed documentary JAMMING ADDIS, of which Melaku is one of the protagonists. If you haven't watched it yet, do it now: in the clip Melaku speaks about FENDIKA, the Azmari (Ethiopian artists similar to traveling minstrels, more about this below) and the cultural life in his country.  And in the final part of the clip he tells his personal story - which as you will see is quite astonishing.
If you followed the September campaign and know all about Melaku, FENDIKA and Ethiocolor, you can scroll down to the section SO WHAT'S THE PROBLEM? Otherwise, keep reading and watching the other video clips below !
This next clip though is from Melaku's private archives and shows a recent performance at FENDIKA.
(Melaku and his group Ethiocolor at FENDIKA - video courtesy of Melaku Belay)
WHO IS MELAKU BELAY?
Somebody recently has compared Melaku to "a walking meter of ambient electrical activity, translating the vibes on the street into ecstatic dance moves". Others say he is something like "a walking earthquake". 


Melaku in "his" taxi 
Melaku worked his way up from being a street kid to one of the most important cultural operators in Addis Ababa and Ethiopia, and of wide international fame. After a long time sleeping on the streets of Addis, he asked the owners of the FENDIKA if he could sleep there and was given permission. In the coming months he slept behind the bar during the day - at night, he watched performances at the club. "Stealing with his eyes" from their movements, he taught himself how to dance. For nine years, he danced at FENDIKA earning only tips, like all the other Azmaris (musicians, singers etc). And it grew in him that this system had to change, that art is weak if it depends on tips only. 
Melaku worked hard for many years - and today owns the club. Around him, he has created a family of dancers, musicians and performers who are regularly invited to many places around the world, including some of the biggest festivals like Roskilde or Africolor, the Sauti Za Busara Festival in Zanzibar, Africolor Festival and Jazz à la Villette Festival in Paris, TFF Rudolstadt World Music Festival in Germany. Musicians from all around the world visit FENDIKA, including THE EX from Holland, La Tigre Des Platanes, Le Bruit Du Sign and Ukadanz from France, the Imperial Tiger Orchestra from Switzerland and others.   

But the best really is to see the man with your own eyes and begin to feel the joy he emanates. In the next clip from our film you will see how Melaku improvises a dance to the mesmerizing music of pianist Samuel Yirga. Sammy and Melaku are good friends and share a common sentiment for the importance of Ethiopian cultural identity.

(link to this clip on our website)
WHY DOES MELAKU'S WORK MATTER?In the mid 1970s, Ethiopian Anthropologist Tesfaye Lemma and his partner, American Peace Corps volunteer Charles Sutton traveled Ethiopia, discovering singers and musicians in the remotest areas of the country and brought them to Addis. Via national television for the first time Lemma familiarized astonished Ethiopians with their very own musical traditions. His “Orchestra Ethiopia” of traditional musicians brought Ethiopian music to wide international success and even toured the USA. Tesfaye Lemma's work was essential for Ethiopians becoming more and more conscious about their own heritage and the richness of their own musical culture. 
Yohannes Afework, member of "Orchestra Ethiopia" and of Melaku's "Ethiocolor"Today, many say that Melaku is the rightful bearer of Lemma's artistic and spiritual heritage. Some members of the "Orchestra Ethiopia" who worked with legendary Tesfaye Lemma are still alive, most of them work with Melaku in FENDIKA. Flutist Yohannes Afework is one of the ancient members of the "Orchestra Ethiopia" and  participated in the orchestra's famous tour through the US. During a recent lunch meeting at the Ras Hotel, Yohannes surprised all of us, most of all Melaku himself, with what he had to say:

 (link to this clip on our website)
THE AZMARI'S FUNCTION IN ETHIOPIA
Since
 the beginning of time, the Azmari have been Ethiopia's artists: 
singers, musicians or poets. They are story-tellers within the ancient 
tradition of bardic minstrels, similar to the troubadours in European 
culture. Azmaris are free thinkers who since the dawn of time were 
allowed to speak the truth at the king's court even when everybody else 
shut up.


above and below: rehearsal at FENDIKA

Azmari culture is hundreds if not thousands of years old. But their social function is still the same in 
contemporary Ethiopia: Azmaris speak about social and political 
issues, about HIV and culture, or simply about the things that happen in
 the world.  Within the protection that music and lyrics provide to 
them, Azmaris can say what nobody else can (or dares to say).
WHAT'S SO SPECIAL ABOUT FENDIKA?
The
 Azmari's art to wrap the message in music, lyrics, a song or 
masterfully recited poetry requires talent, practice and a lot of 
exercise. But for all that dedication, the only means of wages Azmaris 
can aspire to are tips. The concept of "real pay" for artists does not 
exists. 
Historically this "tipping system" made them depend 
on the whim of their "masters" and the favor of local rulers. And it is 
no surprise that most Azmaris are constantly one step away from total 
insecurity. Or, in Melaku Belay's words: "As an Azmari you have to focus
 on survival, where to get enough food and a place to sleep. Like this, 
art becomes weak". 


"Tipping" legendary singer Zeritu Getahun during her performance
Azmaris can't show their art where they 
want: in the past it was the ruler's court, today the venues are reduced
 to very few places. FENDIKA is such a place, called azmari bet
 or "House of the Azmari". And, what is almost more important, FENDIKA 
is the first and until today only venue in Addis that provides the 
artists with a fair and secure pay, instead of keeping them dependent on
 being tipped by customers or tourists.
In fact, when Melaku 
took over FENDIKA almost two decades ago, he immediately established 
regular stipends for the Azmari. This was unheard of in Addis and 
Ethiopia, and it meant a revolutionary step forward toward artistic 
independence and freedom. Hence, FENDIKA is economically balanced: the 
income generated by selling tickets and beverages are used to pay the 
artists and the club's maintenance. 
As flute player Yohannes Afework says in the previous clip, Melaku is doing a great job in keeping the memory of the older Azmari artists alive: FENDIKA is the only place in Addis where many of them can still find enthusiastic audiences.  The next clip will give you an impressive example: Zeritu Getahun began her career in the 1950s (!) and today, at the age of… (who knows) is a regular guest at FENDIKA. Listen to Melaku introducing her as the voice that an entire generation grew up with, and watch her singing one of her best-known tunes in front of an enchanted crowd.
(link to this clip on our website)

MELAKU'S GROUP ETHIOCOLOR
In 2009, one year after Melaku took over the FENDIKA, he also founded his own group of musicians and called it ETHIOCOLOR. Playing at FENDIKA every second Friday of the month, Ethiocolor is an innovative Ethiopian traditional band consisting of Kirar (a kind of lyre), Bass Kirar, Washint (flute), Kebero (traditional drums) and Massinqo. 


Ethiocolor live in Copenhagen, October 29th, 2014 (courtesy of the Paal Nilssen-Love curated Actionjazz Festival)“Our goal is not just to assemble traditional musicians and create another folk ensemble. Our vision is to demonstrate that the immense musical heritage of Ethiopia can be performed with a great degree of creativity while still maintaining its identity” says Melaku about Ethiocolor.

Each member of the group has extensive experience in Ethiopia and internationally. Ethiocolor's musicians and dancers have work with traditional music but also with jazz, rock, fusion and hip hop. This gives Ethiocolor's music a special edge. Indeed, since its inception in 2009, word has spread fast for the young group of musicians, dancers and singers. After winning a wide audience in Addis Ababa and Ethiopia, they began traveling the world. 


And Ethiocolor's members do not only perform inside the FENDIKA, as you can see from the images below taken during this year's Epiphany festivities… 



Melaku and members of Ethiocolor during "timket" (Epiphany) 2014 
ALL THIS SUCCESS - SO WHAT'S THE PROBLEM?!?You're right, this is exactly the question we asked ourselves when we first came to Addis Ababa. And then we started seeing cranes and construction sites everywhere and huge areas where people used to live being prepared for the construction of shopping malls and expensive residential buildings.  Ethiopia is on the brink of becoming a part of the globalized world - but it is not yet. Therefore, some things here are… wild.
Addis Ababa's growing new skyline in 2014Addis Ababa today is seeing an unprecedented rush on construction. Investors mostly from the Middle East and Asia are buying land for low prices and start building hotels or shopping malls on it. This is especially true for the KASANCHIS neighborhood. Once a peripheral area for the less wealthy and north to the city center, Kasanchis has become one of the most popular areas in the very heart of Addis Ababa. 

A map of the central areas of Addis; Kasanchis begins about in the map's center - the red dot in the upper right half is where FENDIKA is located. If you want to find FENDIKA on GoogleMaps, put "Fendika Azmari Bet" into the search field and you'll find it.Kasanchis is the home of FENDIKA CULTURAL CLUB since more than 30 years. And Melaku lives nearby. In the past two-three years, the neighborhood is being swamped with many new buildings, and most of those cement monsters have been risen up without any other criteria than fast profit. Even residential spaces often have their windows at only a few inches from the concrete wall of the building next to it. 


Addis Ababa's symbol before a skeleton made of concrete
Back in September, our first IndieGoGo campaign SAVE FENDIKA was a huge success: with the more than 20.000 Dollars Melaku was able to make a down payment to the owner of the land FENDIKA is built on. The land was not sold to foreign investors - instead Melaku got the option to buy it himself.   
But now Melaku needs to complete the payment and to fulfill his agreement. Once again, Melaku and his "Azmari family" of dancers, musicians and cultural operators are calling for help upon their friends all around the world - and this is the final call. 
To finish paying the land and keep FENDIKA safe once and for all, until mid December Melaku must find the remaining money and pay off the owner. Friends, cultural investors, private money and most of all the September INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN helped getting closer to that goal. But even with all that support, of the 75.000 Dollars Melaku needs, less than half of this amount has been collected until today.

constructions and a sky full of "vultures" - quite symbolic…
  Melaku Belay began to launch his own initiative for FENDIKA through Facebook (see here). However, the country's internet is in "prehistoric" conditions. Access to the world wide web lags, speeds are way below what we were used to in the West in the mid 1990s. Even in Addis Ababa, the country's capital, except from some foreign institutions and embassies the internet is extremely slow. To open a Facebook page, Ethiopians have to wait for several minutes - to upload the 330 MBs of the videoclip that comes with this initiative would take more than a week if you did it from Addis... 
All this is why we want to help Melaku on his quest to safe FENDIKA: we want to enable him and his people - his "Azmari family" - to stay where they are and continue their work. Melaku and FENDIKA are already established as a "cultural hub" that is vital for Addis Ababa and important for the rebuilding if the Ethiopian cultural identity. 

We want Melaku to continue his work, to maintain FENDIKA and to build a cultural center on top of the old club building that he will finally own. We are convinced that the Azmaris need Fendika (to survive). Addis needs Fendika (to have a conscience). Ethiopia needs Fendika (to maintain the memory of the past and connect it with the present). And ultimately, we believe that Africa needs Fendika (to keep up the cultural diversity in one of the continent's most diverse and multi-ethnic countries - they call Ethiopia "little Africa" for a reason). 


Ethiocolor performing in FENDIKA

CAMPAIGN TEAMSo who are we and why do we care? All of us have personal and professional  reasons for being attached to FENDIKA and Melaku. Dirk van den Berg  is a director/producer with extensive international experience based in Berlin, Germany. Between December 2013 and June 2014, Dirk and his team were in Addis Ababa for several times, filming the documentary JAMMING ADDIS. Melaku Belay almost immediately became one of the film's protagonists. More importantly, they became friends. Dirk learned to admire Melaku's passion for Ethiopian culture, his incredible strength and charismatic will-force in his fight for culture. He shares Melaku's belief that culture is one of the most essential building parts for any national identity.  
Lynne Williamson is a folklorist and the director of the Connecticut Cultural Heritage Arts Program. With experience developing cultural heritage projects in the UK and US, she has been assisting FENDIKA and Melaku with touring in the US, communications and fundraising.

THE PRESS SAYS ABOUT MELAKU… 
Melaku has meticulously collected press articles from all over the world on his home page. Here are the most important articles and press clippings, beginning with a New York Times publication from only a few days ago:  
In Ethiopia’s Capital, a Resurgent Jazz Scene (Nov 13, 2014)
Ethiopia has been home to 'Azmari Bets' — taverns featuring sung comedy accompanied by a lyre — for centuries, but what the Ethiocolor Band does at Fendika is quite different. Led by the charismatic Addis-born dancer Melaku Belay, the 13-member group has reimagined traditional Ethiopian culture for the 21st century, combining tribal dances and indigenous instruments with jazz, rock, theater and lots of costume changes. On a recent late night, the crowd that gathered around the dancers — wearing spiky wigs made from the hair of gelada baboons — was invited to show off their skills at the 'eskista', a shoulder-shaking jig.“I believe tradition is never stuck,” Mr. Belay said. The self-taught dancer, who is 38, had first come to the place where the Ethiocolor Band performed when he was a child living on the street. Mr. Belay said that he’d slept under the bar for seven years, earning his board by working without pay. Many years later he bought Fendika Azmari Bet from its former owners and began to shake up the city’s cultural life. As he put it, “I am the bridge to connect jazz and theater to azmaris.”
NEW YORK TIMES - Where Feet, Beat and Joy All Soar Funkily (12 August 2011)
It was a delight to watch and the rhythmic virtuosity of Melaku was often astounding. He can turn either the upper or the lower body into an electrifying vehicle of rapid pulsation. One dance was all to do with his throwing his feet out before him (as if on hot coals). Sometimes the feet alternated, sometimes he hopped, and on one occasion, while hopping brilliantly, he mimed strumming on the other leg, which he kept stretched out like a guitar. 
 BBC folk - Ethiopia (26 February 2010)
Another inspirational individual we met was a man called Melaku Belay. Melaku was a Sudanese refugee. His family was dispersed, and he ended up as an orphan and street kid in Addis Ababa. To survive he danced for tips at a music club, where he asked if he could sleep on floor. He managed to earn enough tips to eventually buy the club - an amazing feat! He is now a world famous dancer, performing with the Ethiopiques, yet he always comes home to dance in his club and invest in the community. 


THE REPORTER - Clapping, dancing the night away 

‘Ethiopia’ is a single by the renowned American rock band, the Red Hot Chili Peppers. This single was inspired when one band member visited Ethiopia and on his stay here performed at Fendika, and the energy he felt there inspired the band to do a song entitled ‘Ethiopia’. This energy Red Hot Chili Peppers talks about is the feeling many feel when they come to Fendika located in Kazanchis. The owner of Fendika, Melaku Belay remembers twenty years ago how the Azmari places were famous, where the older generation used to come and the poems they used to give for Azmaris were matured ones. And also ten years ago all the Azmari places were flourishing; now most of the businesses have changed.
Melaku somehow tried to give new meaning to Azmaris, paying the Azmaris, since their livelihoods was totally dependent on rewards from the customers...  

ADDIS RUMBLE - Impromptu Addis 
Melaku Belay is one of the sweetest souls I have ever met. I didn’t know him, but I had watched him dance at his traditional azmari bet‘Fendika’ in Addis (one of the best bars in the world!). He’s also in many video’s dancing with The Ex and with Getatchew Mekuria so I thought it would be great to work with him – to find a way to harness his energy into a very kinetic film – but also to show a bit of his skill at getting the people around him involved.



Melaku dancing with Samuel Yirga at "Mama's Kitchen" 
PERKS
You donate to support FENDIKA and Melaku's work - so we are not spending money on meaningless swag that will collect dust under your bed. However, we plan to offer authentic Ethiopian clothes and jewelry, and we will create videos and music so you can share FENDIKA's cultural adventure. 
Promising you to send you goods and gadgets is impossible right now: you can't send any objects from Ethiopia to other countries without being subject to ludicrously high taxes. An Ethiopian dress that costs 10 Dollars in a Kasanchis shop would cost 80 Dollars in taxes and shipping costs. We think that wasting your donations in this way would be a contradiction in terms.  But: all donations will be noticed, each contribution will be recognized. And yes, you can also donate privately. We are grateful for your support.  
In the pane to the right we have more details on some perks that we know we can promise. Keep in mind that you can contribute also without claiming a perk, and whatever you think is right to give to this campaign.  
Without further ado, here come the perks: 
$10 – A photo of Ethiocolor taken at Fendika, with signatures of all band members and a dedication on your name
$25 -  CD mixtape put together by Melaku: this is actually what everybody who comes to FENDIKA asks Melaku to do. And he won't do it because the treasure of LPs and Singles he has is part of FENDIKA's allure for the audiences. For this campaign, he will make an exception, so expect these CDs to grow value as collector's items over time. 
$50 – A scarf from Addis, like the ones worn by dancers. Or if you want it more "natural", we can try to get you one actually worn by the dancers. 
$75 – Free entrance for life at FENDIKA + the 25$ perk (CD mixtape) 
$100 - Free entrance for life at FENDIKA + the 25$ perk (CD mixtape) + the 50$ perk (a scarf from Addis)  
$200 – a praise song in your honour, created by a real Azmari, recorded and sent to you
$500 – guided tour of Addis given to you by Melaku, including the mythical "MERKATO" area
The Addis "merkato" (from the Italian word for "market") is arguably the largest open-air market area on the entire African continent. The following video shows Melaku's experimental performance at merkato some years back. He literally used the sounds,  rhythms and movements of the market's skilful workers and their materials, transforming them with the use of traditional Ethiopian esktista and guragigna  dance. Melaku called his experiment Ahun, which means "Now": on the one hand this underlines the inspirational moment for Melaku's performance, on the other it  captures the continuous transformation of the huge open-air market (note: there is some text in the beginning, the actual video begins at 1'10''). 


Ahun - Now, Melaku's solo performance in 2011 at the merkato area  (video courtesy of Zeleman Production Addis Ababa)
THE IMPACT OF THIS CAMPAIGN
Perhaps the "big bang" moment for modern Ethiopian music was in 1924, when a brass-band the Emperor brought from a foreign country became Ethiopia's first official orchestra. Until the 1950s, institutional bands dominated, like the Army, the Police and others. But in the mid 1960s musicians began to fuse Jazz, Soul and Rhythm'n'Blues with the traditional Ethiopian five-note scale and the famous "modes" (remember them all? Tezeta, Bati, Anchihoye and of course Ambassel). Ethiopian music reached its first peak in modern times  that became universally known as 'Swinging Addis'. But when the grim Marxist regime of the 'Derg' took power in 1974, it killed 'Swinging Addis' - like it killed almost everything else. Many were murdered, many escaped, most to America. All cultural life was paralyzed. When the horror finished in 1987, only a few musicians found their way back. It took until the second decade of the 21st century that a new generation of Ethiopians began to fill the void. Melaku is one of the protagonists of this generation.  
Ethiopia is an ancient country - and at the same time, it is very young: it was only thirty years ago that the military government collapsed and the country could slowly begin to rebuild itself. And only today, a new generation of Ethiopians begins to feel that once again, their country has a cultural identity. For two decades now, Melaku and his "Azmari Family" have been essential for this process of rebuilding and reconstitution. If FENDIKA disappears, they will disappear - or at least they will be without a home and a space where to experiment and to create their art.   
Your contribution will allow Melaku, the Azmaris and the FENDIKA to continue to exist. And with that, to continue contributing to rebuild young Ethiopians' identities. Together with Melaku we believe that culture is an essential building part for the national identity of a people. With your donation, you help to continue doing this. 


early morning at Fendika: cleaning after an opening night
 
 OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Any financial contribution is appreciated; even 5 Dollars or Euros help us to reach our goal. And there are many other ways you can help:
   •   Use the IndieGoGo share icons above to distribute our campaign to your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Google+ and whatever other flavor you prefer.   •   Write about our campaign on your blog, website, or publication. We are happy to provide promotional material, and will in turn share your link on our social media channels.   •   Start listening to Ethiopian Music and see if it gets you as addicted to pentatonic melodies and African rhythms  as us. And if that is so, talk to your friends about our campaign.And last but not least - check back often. Updates will  be frequent in the coming weeks.


Addis cranes and a plane leaving at sunset

story:
****UPDATE AUGUST 2011***


We are half way through our campaign and very behind our funding goal - please we are urging people to give kindly so we can keep our services available for our community - with the recent riots in London - communities need to come together to look out for eachother and our youth as their future is often not guaranteed. Please keep us alive as we are needed more than ever.


Our Story

 

ROTA Entertainment is an independent youth-led media company that aims to change the way young people are viewed in the global media. Founded by a group of charismatic young people across the globe in 2010; ROTA has been able to build global contacts through proper marketing, youth seminars, community events and social media forums.

 

 

THE IMPACT

 

The company has been able to produce some small scale community events in London and also successfully produce the UK hit show “Once upon a time in the 90s” which unfortunately must be shelved after only being able to do a two day showcase due to lack of cohesion and co-operation, and unprofessionalism from dishonest, manipulative and exploitative third parties who were involved in the production side of the project and wanted to take advantage of young people through Blackmail. These unfortunate events have led to the company losing a major deal that would have put the company on the map and help us set up bases in the United States and other parts of the world. All community projects have been cancelled and ROTA studios has been closed down until all payments can be made.

 

The devastating impact affects young people around the world who have put a lot of time and effort into promoting supporting and encouraging the company in hopes of seeing it grow and eventually expand to help them have a voice in their respective country of residence. Unfortunately this financial setback has lead to all project being shelved thus causing the entire team to be redundant and the company to face legal action from funders who believed in our vision enough to make a sacrifice so great as bring our masterpiece to life.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get.

 

We urgently seek to raise the immediate amount of $8000 (More if possible to continue future projects) to prevent our company from being shut down. The youth had a voice in ROTA as their ideas, thoughts, emotions, feelings and situations were presented in an entertaining and educating manner. All donations would be broken as stated.


$2000 - would go into paying 3 months rent to keep ROTA studios open in order for all rehearsals of future projects to go on. The benefit of having ROTA studios is that it gives the youth a place to meet and discuss. We also allow other young people to come and host meetings in the space where they can discover their own potential. Small community programmes like a sunday soup kitchen and a youth free breakfast club have often been carried out bu ROTA in order to extend our hand to the community.


$3000- would go towards the development of two of ROTA's future projects "Blood of a nation" and "Once upon a time in the 90s" - The benefit of productions is that they give the youth temporary employment and help them develop their creative skills in an environment for them by them. These productions help challenge the minds of our youth by providing them with alternative views of what they should be doing in society and not who they are perceived as.


$3000- Would go towards hiring a new production team of professionals in order to ensure that future projects are a success. We would negotiate contracts which would be handled by a professional solicitor in order for ROTA to be able to avoid any issues in the future. We plan to expand into both film and Television in order to reach a wider audience.


Your contribution allows us to continue to take our community projects as well as media projects to new heights. We will continue to train young people and challenge their thought process by putting on more seminars; not only in the London area but online, so it will be accessible to everyone.

 

If for any unfortunate reason we do not reach our funding goal; the company would have to shut down and some of the most inspiring stories would never be told. Your donation goes towards the youth

– the future of our world lies in the hand of the youth of today; if they are not properly nourished this leads to all sorts of anti-social behaviour and problems to society. ROTA eradicates and challenges stereotypes that affect the self esteem of young people around the world – but telling OUR story; we find a common ground, all the support ROTA provides cannot continue without your support.

 

Other ways you could help.

 

Please spread the word around via Twitter, Facebook, Bebo, Myspace, Youtube etc – Sharing is caring.

 

 

If you are interested in knowing more about ROTA then please visit our website www.rotaentertainment.com.
story_txt:
****UPDATE AUGUST 2011***

We are half way through our campaign and very behind our funding goal - please we are urging people to give kindly so we can keep our services available for our community - with the recent riots in London - communities need to come together to look out for eachother and our youth as their future is often not guaranteed. Please keep us alive as we are needed more than ever. 

Our Story
 
ROTA Entertainment is an independent youth-led media company that aims to change the way young people are viewed in the global media. Founded by a group of charismatic young people across the globe in 2010; ROTA has been able to build global contacts through proper marketing, youth seminars, community events and social media forums.
 
 
THE IMPACT
 
The company has been able to produce some small scale community events in London and also successfully produce the UK hit show “Once upon a time in the 90s” which unfortunately must be shelved after only being able to do a two day showcase due to lack of cohesion and co-operation, and unprofessionalism from dishonest, manipulative and exploitative third parties who were involved in the production side of the project and wanted to take advantage of young people through Blackmail. These unfortunate events have led to the company losing a major deal that would have put the company on the map and help us set up bases in the United States and other parts of the world. All community projects have been cancelled and ROTA studios has been closed down until all payments can be made. 
 
The devastating impact affects young people around the world who have put a lot of time and effort into promoting supporting and encouraging the company in hopes of seeing it grow and eventually expand to help them have a voice in their respective country of residence. Unfortunately this financial setback has lead to all project being shelved thus causing the entire team to be redundant and the company to face legal action from funders who believed in our vision enough to make a sacrifice so great as bring our masterpiece to life.
 
 
What We Need & What You Get.
 
We urgently seek to raise the immediate amount of $8000 (More if possible to continue future projects) to prevent our company from being shut down. The youth had a voice in ROTA as their ideas, thoughts, emotions, feelings and situations were presented in an entertaining and educating manner. All donations would be broken as stated.

$2000 - would go into paying 3 months rent to keep ROTA studios open in order for all rehearsals of future projects to go on. The benefit of having ROTA studios is that it gives the youth a place to meet and discuss. We also allow other young people to come and host meetings in the space where they can discover their own potential. Small community programmes like a sunday soup kitchen and a youth free breakfast club have often been carried out bu ROTA in order to extend our hand to the community.

$3000- would go towards the development of two of ROTA's future projects "Blood of a nation" and "Once upon a time in the 90s" - The benefit of productions is that they give the youth temporary employment and help them develop their creative skills in an environment for them by them. These productions help challenge the minds of our youth by providing them with alternative views of what they should be doing in society and not who they are perceived as.

$3000- Would go towards hiring a new production team of professionals in order to ensure that future projects are a success. We would negotiate contracts which would be handled by a professional solicitor in order for ROTA to be able to avoid any issues in the future. We plan to expand into both film and Television in order to reach a wider audience. 

Your contribution allows us to continue to take our community projects as well as media projects to new heights. We will continue to train young people and challenge their thought process by putting on more seminars; not only in the London area but online, so it will be accessible to everyone. 
 
If for any unfortunate reason we do not reach our funding goal; the company would have to shut down and some of the most inspiring stories would never be told. Your donation goes towards the youth – the future of our world lies in the hand of the youth of today; if they are not properly nourished this leads to all sorts of anti-social behaviour and problems to society. ROTA eradicates and challenges stereotypes that affect the self esteem of young people around the world – but telling OUR story; we find a common ground, all the support ROTA provides cannot continue without your support. 

 
Other ways you could help. 
 
Please spread the word around via Twitter, Facebook, Bebo, Myspace, Youtube etc – Sharing is caring. 
 
 
If you are interested in knowing more about ROTA then please visit our website www.rotaentertainment.com.

story:
OUR STORY

About 13 years ago after working some very back breaking jobs a relative and I started to compare paychecks. She was just starting to act and go out for auditions. Despite having a Masters in a different field of study she just wanted to try out this "acting thing". Amazingly enough 3 of her paychecks ( in a row!) from her 1 hour to 1 day's worth of acting were bigger than my 2 week's worth of work at horrible temp jobs and physically abusive factory/shipping work. Oddly enough she lost interest in acting ( because of her Masters) and found better paying work elsewhere, HOWEVER, I after that third time decided to throw my hat into the ring. My first gig was with a MAJOR cable network and I have never looked back!

Over the 13 years I have changed. I went from acting to novel and screenwriting. After people expressed interest in my writing a good friend of mine asked "Why don't you film that yourself?" So I did and SAPIEN FILMS was born!!!! SAPIEN FILMS over the pass 4 years has filmed many short films in many genres. People seem most intrigued by our horror and suspense work. We even created a horror and suspense series called THE HUMAN GAME which is due to premiere it's 3rd episode sometime next year. We are even planning our first feature length film called BOY: A Story Based On True Events next year (it, too, has an IndieGoGo page). Yet, this is just the tip of the iceberg! We are in the works to produce 4 more films and pilots for TV.


WHY YOU SHOULD CARE

A home. We need a home.  Currently, we do not have a place to call our headquarters. My apt. is way too small and the public library gets weary of overly frequent meeting and auditions. HOW CAN YOU HELP? Easy. We are in talks with a local theater about partnership. The owner is looking for funds to keep his facility open. This theater is located right off the highway and for all actors, producers, and crew involved this location is extremely convienent. If we help keep his doors open he  has promised to let us use his available space as HQ. In return we will also provide a volunteer staff that will answer phones and keep the place looking a 100% immaculate (and yes I will mop, sweep, and dust if not spit shine (yuk) that place to perfection because I am dedicated)!


WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

$35,000 is what we really need for now. $25,000 will guarantee that The theater's doors will stay open. The extra $10,000 will help fund our movies which you can see by the demo range from horror and suspense to action and drama (I am seriously working on doing comedy on film but for now the darker stuff is paramount)! On top of that this facility is the only theater in NJ area that offers all artists (filmmakers, stand-up, muscians) the walk-in opportunity to perform or show their work before the actual show. You literally can call a day or sooner and book space if the schedule permits. It is a wonderful facility which will help SAPIEN FILMS and myself grow in the right direction. No more having meetings in my Mom's music room or backyard. No more sneaking people and having to find already inconvienent parking at my apt. complex! No more filling out paperwork in the children's room of the library and hoping that there is a clear day on the schedule that all cast and crew can meet!!! Please help SAPIEN FILMS FIND A HOME WHERE WE CAN CREATE FREELY!


HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

The links are on this page. PLEASE spread the word and pass these links onto others like your friends, neighbors, and colleagues. Nothing is impossible if your heart is determined and you put your mind to it... And with support from people such as yourself DREAMS DO COME TRUE. Thank you for your time, consideration, and efforts towards our goals.

story:
My Story

 

Dear Friends,

 

My name is Stephanie and I am in the process of launching Resurgam (which in Latin stands for ‘I shall Rise Again’), a Portland Maine based custom sewing, alterations and upholstery business with a focus on repurposed materials. To me having my own business is about having the ability to express creativity in a way that is true to my transformative approach to art and the use of materials.  It is a purpose I am passionate about and have been working toward since my early 20’s. I’m a seamstress to the core, and can’t see myself doing anything else. With my ambition and your generous support we can anchor this dream in Portland Maine!!!


I am now close to realizing the goal I have worked towards in the form of an all-in-one shop for personally repurposed goods. The shop will include a retail section, a working shop with customization services focusing on both alterations and upholstery, and a gallery for local artisan's work.  The business I envision will channel and magnify my creative energy into something that will produce exceptional products in a sustainable way while enhancing the quality of life in my community.

 

What’s not to love about that!?!?

 

The Impact

 

Resurgam’s services include:

·         Repurposing goods, such as: clothing by way of alterations, re-upholstering vintage furniture, along with other home goods needs. Our goal is to add a face-to-face aspect of the business; the services at Resurgam will happen in the shop in full view of customers. So many products are created overseas and shipped for great distances before they reach the shelves of local stores. Allowing the consumer a chance to see works in progress will encourage a feeling of connection to the products and an appreciation for the ageless trade of sewing. 

·        The second part of the shop will be retail, for which will include a unique inventory of custom apparel, reupholstered furniture and home accessories. All products will lovingly emerge from repurposed materials.

·        Finally the shop will also act as an art gallery.  Resurgam will be a place where local creators of sustainable and or recycled jewelry, weavings and art can consign.  One artist per month can showcase their pieces, which will be promoted during events, such as the monthly art walk. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We Need:


Here is a list if supplies I need to get started:

 

Prices estimated for studio space and equipment

12 months rent for initial studio space $4,500

Industrial sewing machine $1200

Pattern making table $200

Body form $180

Electric staple gun $120

Total: $6,200

 

With these basic necessities I will be equipped to launch Resurgam. Your support is an opportunity to contribute to my vision of a sustainable business with an engaging, artistic atmosphere that creates a unique product. I will appreciate any contribution, large or small.  


You Get:

As funders, you will receive one of an array of perks as outlined in the 'perk' section above, receive web-updates on the status of this fundraiser and the business later on, the satisfaction of being a part of starting a great business and knowing that you made a dream come true!!

If you don't want to make a donation but like the project, simply helping by spreading the word anywhere possible is much appreciated! Also, follow us on facebook and twitter for sewing tips and links to other excellent Maine-based small businesses.

 

Thank you so much!

 

Stephanie

story:
www.incendiaryintent.com

Incendiary Intent returns to the playa for 2012 with spicier vodka, more torturous challenge beers, and spicy delicious treats.  (candy anyone?)

 

What We Need for 2012:

Funds raised in 2012 will be used to cover camp costs.

The biggest of these is the truck and trailer to haul out all our metal infrastructure - $1200

And gas for said truck - $400

Another $300 goes to cover our bar night supplies, including our hand crafted black pepper vodka, and chili pepper vodka, and mixers.

Our Challenge, even using the cheapist, most terrible beer we can find is $200.

The remaining $400 goes to cover things like rebuilding our infrastructure, year round storage, our WoW event on Saturday, and inevitably, more beer for the Challenge.

Total funds needed: $2,500

 

This will be Incendiary Intent's 4th year on the Playa, and we look forward to continuing what we started.  

We're bringing back our Challenge, which makes everyone cry, but they love us anyways...

We're never totally sure why people keep coming back to us for this, but we love each and every one of you.  Terrible, spicy burning, cheap beer love.  The vodka is only getting hotter, and the beer is only getting cheaper and worse.  Come on by.  Bring your friends.  Bring your friends that you're a little mad at for stealing the last piece of bacon at breakfast this morning.  Bring your enemies, and your friends and your lovers, but we don't recommend kissing for awhile after...

Some great images of our Challenge in years past: http://www.incendiaryintent.com/?page_id=117

And our fantastic Challenge diary book full of fantastic commentary:

http://www.incendiaryintent.com/?page_id=557

-Pour Some Fire Down Your Throat bar nights, which this year, Incendiary Sugar girls will be serving spicy delicious candies and sweets while you enjoy tasty drinks...

You know those old school cigarette girls?  We're going to dress up our lovely ladies in those outfits.  WITH the little boxes.  And then, rather than filling them with cotton candy, our ladies will be peddling spicy lollipops of doom (diabetic friendly too!), candied spicy BACON, spicy sweet popcorn, and my personal favorite, spicy pixie sticks!!!  And as we do more "research", we might find more spicy delicious treats to include - we welcome suggestions for things to try out!!

Up at the bar, we'll be serving a variety of spicy booze, and sweet cold mixers!  We have some new cocktails to try out this year, and we're looking forward to sharing them with you!  And of course, we'll be bringing back our classic "Motor Oil" drink for those that don't quite like the spice.  You have to trust us, but it's delicious!

-Gastronmae Dominae with new, strange delights for you to eat and lounge with....

Including pb&j noodles, bacon powder, and Arnold Palmer bobas!  We had a blast serving strange and interesting food to people last year, and drinking delicious absinthe and relaxing in the shade with new friends, and we're looking forward to bringing new and interesting foods with us!  

-Wow addicts recovery meeting on Saturday!  Wouldn't want to forget our awesome nerd friends! :)

Delicious Chocolate Cake.  Raspberry Kungaloosh.  Need I say more?  If I do....epic Lootz!  Nerdy conversation!  Shade!  You can have delicious chocolate cake AND alcohol even if you're NOT a nerd!!  All non and nerd people are welcome!

-And assorted other foolishness, debauchery, and wickedness!

Including a return of the wickedly delicious spicy sno-cones.  There's nothing quite like a cup full of shaved ice, drowning in syrup, and that first delicious cold icy sweet bite....and then the slow build of delicious spicy heat!   

 

Perks will be sent (if applicable) in late July!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please spread the word!  There are these awesome share tools made available here, and we would appreciate if you could share this on your facebook, or twitter, or whathaveyou.  We would also appreciate if you came by to say hello out on the playa this year!!

story: The campaign is now over Many thanks to our supporters.
story_txt: The campaign is now over Many thanks to our supporters.

story:
Our Story

My name is Caitlynn and my husbands name is Skyler. We are already legally married as of 19 May, 2010. Meeting him is one of the best things that has ever happened to me. We got married at a park in Jerome, Arizona with only closest of friends. Now we would like to have the whole ceremony with all of our friends and family sharing our joy. Skyler is in film school and I am working towards a Certified Nurse Midwife degree. Being college kids, we can't afford much and don't expect to. We are saving as much as possible. This campaign is to help just that extra little bit with ceremony-related expenses.


The Impact

This is really the first time all of our family will be together and for some family, it will be the first time either of us have seen any of them in a long while. We just want them to enjoy their time as much as possible. The ceremony and reception/reunion will happen regardless of this campaign, it would just be nice to have a bit of wiggle room.

What We Need & What You Get

We would like $500 for unexpected expenses and to help with the already-expected ones. As I said before, it will take place either way, it would just be nice to have some cushion. Unfortunately, the only perk I can think of is a video from the ceremony uploaded to youtube thanking individuals for their donations (Unless you want a bottle of bubbles)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't or do not wish to donate,please just pass it onto others, using facebook, twitter, or which ever social network suits you best! Remember, ANYTHING you can do would be greatly appreciated!
