story:
Our Story

"Our mission is to fight HIV/AIDS by building a movement of young leaders dedicated to global health equity and social justice."
 

Hey everyone!  We are FACE AIDS at New York University.  FACE AIDS is a vibrant, supportive, and diverse peer community for youth, through which they can move from being dedicated but disconnected individuals to being an impactful coalition of leaders who learn from and support one another.  As members of this growing non-profit organization, we are dedicated to the eradication of inequalities plaguing those directly affected by the HIV/AIDS pandemic, both domestically and internationally. Founded in 2005 by three Stanford students, FACE AIDS is still a relatively young organization, but we are proud to say that we are at over 210 high schools, colleges, and universities and growing by the minute.  


"We are ambitious and optimistic, and focus on opportunities for change and impact."


Since its creation, FACE AIDS has had a strong relationship with Partners in Health, a non-profit organization committed to providing the "highest quality of care to the 2.4 million" impoverished people it now serves worldwide.  FACE AIDS works mainly with PIH and its many Rwandan sites helping to bring quality healthcare and resources to those often overlooked and underfunded by the world.  This year, PIH has asked FACE AIDS to sponsor the rehabilitation and revitalization of Nyamirama Health Center in Eastern Rwanda.  To meet the challenge, FACE AIDS has pledged to raise 185,000 USD.  FACE AIDS at NYU, has pledged to raise 4,000 USD.  While we know it is quite an ambitious goal, we know that we can raise it, with your help of course!


Nyamirama Health Center

"It is about fulfilling a community's hope"


Located directly off of the main highway that runs straight from Rwanda’s capital city to the border of Tanzania, Nyamirama Health Center is connected to a reliable supply of electricity, and is easily accessible to the roadside community of over 25,000 that it serves. Despite these advantages and the fact that it serves the largest catchment area in the district, Nyamirama has faced incredible challenges and has been extremely underfunded in the past. The center’s facilities consist of two small buildings, neither of which is well-suited to medical care. In one of the buildings, a laboratory doubles as a vaccination room during busy childhood immunization campaigns. Due largely to the overwhelming need of the local community, the Ministry of Health has placed Nyamirama as its top priority to receive additional support in Kayonza District.


The Impact

"Our work is driven by our commitment to a larger vision of a world without HIV/AIDS, a world in which all people have equal access to high-quality, comprehensive health care, and by our belief that our generation can and must be the one to make this vision a reality."

 

Your support of Nyamirama Health Center is critical to helping us prove the success of the Rwandan model and to use it to push the limits of global health delivery. With the partnership of the local community and the health center’s enthusiastic and capable director, PIH plans to ramp up its support of Nyamirama Health Center. Doing so will address an obvious and critical gap in the current health system, and our hope is that the health center will have the capacity to provide the full package of basic medical services by the end of the year. With Nyamirama well staffed and equipped, thousands of community members will now be able to make a short trip for a wide range of primary care services, rather than having to travel for hours to other facilities. It is the emphasis on making high-quality medical care such as HIV treatment available in underserved areas such as Nyamirama that makes Rwanda’s health system uniquely hopeful.


The following are just a few of the costs associated with upgrading the Nyamirama Health Center. With these numbers, we hope you can get a better idea of basic costs and see exactly how high-impact your fundraising efforts can be, no matter what the amount.


 

Human Resources

Social Worker Salary: $2,867

Nurse Salaries (8): $22,940

Data Officer Salary: $2,867

 

Community Health

Accomagnateur Salaries (29): $6,244

Community Health Worker Communications: $102


ï¿¼Social and Economic Rights

Transport and Home Visits: $4,655 Social Worker Communication: $102


Medicines and Treatment

Medicine costs: $1,057


Food Security

Inpatient food: $3,491


Infrastructure and Equipment

Generator Fuel: $610

Equipment Needs for Clinical Programs: $410


  

What We Need & What You Get

"Hand in hand, we will set the standard for patient dignity, solidarity, community, and health as a human right"


Our chapter has pledged 4,000 USD which we have committed to raising by May 15, 2012.  With your help, we can reach this goal together.  To show our appreciation, on the side of the window we have provided a list of gifts with the donation amounts allotted to each.
story_txt:
Our Story


"Our mission is to fight HIV/AIDS by building a movement of young leaders dedicated to global health equity and social justice."

 

Hey everyone!  We are FACE AIDS at New York University.  FACE AIDS is a vibrant, supportive, and diverse peer community for youth, through which they can move from being dedicated but disconnected individuals to being an impactful coalition of leaders who learn from and support one another.  As members of this growing non-profit organization, we are dedicated to the eradication of inequalities plaguing those directly affected by the HIV/AIDS pandemic, both domestically and internationally. story:
We can reach our goal of $5,000 in 72 hours – with your support!

Since May 2010, we have provided hot, nutritious meals and social service resources to homeless and hungry men, women and children in our community.  When we began our mission, we were serving from the trunks of our cars.  With time, we have been able to fine-tune our methods – and began setting up a table for the food and coolers for water in an alley under the “el” tracks in Chicago. 

We had been able to collectively do this by pooling our personal finances together, and through the financial contributions and support of our friends.  However, due to financial constraints we had to stop feeding.  We aggressively want to return to the streets to help those in need.

In these challenging times, it is important to note that we cannot do this without you.  We are asking for your support to help get us back in the community where we belong.  Any donation you can share will be greatly appreciated.  Even a dollar will be accepted with gratitude and bring us closer to being able to defray our expenses.

 

WHO WE ARE . . .

In today’s society, we can quickly find ourselves on the side of the table receiving a meal.  We are a group of friends who come together every week to be a blessing to those who (for whatever reason) might be down on the luck.  We try to embody the spirit that if we really are a community then no one should be left alone or allowed to fail. 

We are asking you to hold the same spirit in your heart and help in whatever way you can. 

Even if you cannot help out financially, please spread the word for us.  It all goes a long way to make our community a better place for everyone.

 

Please consider clicking the big pink “CONTRIBUTE NOW” button at the top or bottom of this page.  When you do, you’ll be able to enter the amount you’d like to contribute.  You can donate with a credit card or paypal.

story:
Summary

I want to Go Bananas!, put a smile on people's faces, and add that special touch to any event. 

As a Youth Minister I would dress up in a rented Gorilla suit and surprise kids at restaurants and at school on their birthday.  It was a hit; kids and parents loved it.  I would like to do this again, but perhaps expand to places like children's hospitals.  They do make clothes which I would like to purchase if any funds remain.  A clothed Gorilla might not be as scary.

I am raising funds to purchase the costume, becasue it makes more financial sense to purchase it, instead of throwing money away by renting- plus I would be purchasing one that is very high quality so it will last, and people will appreciate the difference.

With the purchase of this Gorilla costume; with your help, I could Go Bananas! more often. 

What I Need

I need $1575 to purchase the costume and cover shipping.  If there happens to be funds raised above this amount I will purchase some clothes for the gorilla.

If I do not reach my goal- funds would be saved- until I can find the rest.

The Impact

Laughter, Happy Faces, Increased Potassium Levels from eating the bananas, Good Will.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word.  Every little bit will help.  Use tools on this site to get the word out, plus invite your facebook friends and others to join you in helping me to help others to Go Bananas!

story:
Mr. Rooter Plumber, 22, Fatal Accident, Leaves Behind Son, Age 2

The Landon O'Hara Fund has been established for 2 year-old, Landon Christopher Stanley O'Hara.  Fatal accident took Sean O'Hara, the child's father.

Landon will turn 2, on July 24, 2012 without his father.  The brother, Ryan, 19, was flown to UPMC.  Life threatening injuries. Campbell's Funeral Home in Chippewa (Beaver Falls), PA will have details after Wednesday, June 25, 2012

The acccident was violent, throwing the brother's from the Ford Ranger; the younger O'Hara survivor, was driving.

Bob Beall, president of Mr. Rooter Plumbing Pittsburgh/Youngstown says, "My wife and I have fostered 15 children and adopted three.  Our hearts are breaking for Landon who will grow up without his Daddy."  Beall, immediately upon hearing of the Mr. Rooter Plumbing service technician's tragic death, established a Trust Fund for the toddler. 

Landon resides with his mother, Katie Lynn Stanley, Enon Valley, PA 16120. 

Thank you in advance for your generosity to the Landon O'Hara Fund.  Unexpected tragedy as this leaves an entire family and community in shock.

How You Can Help Mr. Rooter Plumbing Help Landon

  • Mr. Rooter Plumbing Pittsburgh is seeking $50,000 for Landon.
  • Everyone who donates will be automatically registered for Mr. Rooter's Daily Tips and will receive Mr. Rooter Plumbing's Valued Customer Protection Plan for five years. (Limited to the first 100 contributors within 100 mile radius of Pittsburgh or Youngstown). 
    (Details at www.mrrootermedia.com)
  • All proceeds go directly to the Landon O'Hara Fund.

story:
Executive Summary

 

Omo Oduduwa Radio (also known as OORadio), based in Marietta, Georgia, provides quality radio programming centered around educating the global community about the traditional aspects of the Yoruba religion, culture, and customs, respectively. In addition, OORadio serves as a platform to discuss topics that affect and plague the African community, such as conflict resolution, the incorporation of traditional African values, adopting a holistic approach to health and wellness, and Yoruba language, and Yoruba culinary studies, to name a few. OORadio is a forum designed to unite and empower Yoruba practitioners worldwide.

 

Hosted by founder Osaremi Lanloke, OORadios weekly shows provide a colloquium where audience listeners can engage in discourse with experts over a variety of subjects. In addition, OORadio offers scholarly formal instruction on the Yoruba religion, culture, and customs, through teleconferences and online classes.



Business Description and Vision

OORadio's vision is to bring traditional Yoruba culture to the 21st Century. OORadio's business purpose is to create a forum, whether through formal classes, online courses, and radio shows, that discuss topics that celebrate, educate, empower and unite Yoruba practitioners throughout the globe. African citizens of the world and enthused students of other cultures, have the ability to become introduced to traditional Yoruba concepts and ideas, have the means to form an alliance between Yorubas on the African continent and Yorubas in the Diaspora, and have the opportunity to be introduced to timeless Yoruba philosophy and concepts. The Yoruba culture has spread all throughout the world, with more than 30 million practitioners worldwide through different religious off-shoots including Candomblé, Lucumí, Shango, Anago, Oyotunji, some aspects of Umbanda, Winti, Obeah, and Vodun. These religious off-shoots not only provide an opportunity for an interchange of information, but also contain a virtually untapped market that is ripe with potential. OORadio acknowledges that we are in the midst of a cultural, spiritual, and religious revolution.

Scholars all over are searching for an opportunity to learn about other forms of religious expression, to study a robust, ancient culture, and to become educated about the African ways of commerce, politics, and the family unit. People want to know how to maintain meaningful traditions while living in a fast-paced, modern society. People are interested in fulfilling their destiny and purpose, from an African perspective.

 

Presently, OORadio is looking to expand its market share by providing an avenue in which to address all of the aforementioned topics, and then some. This is accomplished by connecting cultural custodians, key politicians, dignitaries, priests, celebrities, and the like, with novices who want to gain access to the Yoruba world. OORadio plans on expanding into different media such as online video streaming and television shows. In addition, OORadio will be support trans-Atlantic business liaisons.

 

Radio programs are hosted under the umbrella of OORadio:

 

Ifa Code of Conduct hosted by Ifategunse Osadele (Sundays 8-9 pm EST)

 

Omo Oduduwa Radio, hosted by Osaremi Lanloke (Tuesday 8-10 pm EST)

 

Engage the Spirit, hosted by Iya Osunkemi Ajewunmi (Thursday 8-9 pm EST)

  

Definition of the Market

 

Presently, there are a variety of online radio shows that provide information on distinct topics such as Yoruba religion (Ifa), holistic medicine, and African cultural restoration. However, few have actually integrated all of the aforementioned concepts. This business is unique in that it integrates both the spiritual and cultural aspects of the traditional Yoruba belief system (Ifa) into one integral component. In addition, Ms. Lanloke's connections are unparalleled; Ms. Lanloke is connected to a bevy of Yoruba priests, thus creating a virtual nexus of Yoruba practitioners, from the shores of Benin to villages in Brazil.

 

It is estimated that there are over 30 million practitioners worldwide. OORadio's present target market entails internet-savvy Yoruba practitioners and novices who are seeking to increase their knowledge-base about Yoruba spirituality and culture. Statistics have shown that the majority of listeners reside in the United States. OORadio will expand beyond this core audience to gain listeners in other countries besides the United States that have a heavy concentration of Yoruba practitioners. In addition, OORadio will be hosting upcoming shows that will feature scholarly experts and priests that originate in locations other than the United States and Nigeria.

 

OORadio has designs on capitalizing on all facets of social utilty (Twitter /Facebook /blogtalkradio) to gain media exposure. Moreover, OORadio is looking to gain exposure through international e-zines (online magazines) and magazines that focus on religion, spirituality, and culture. OORadio is committed to reciprocal support with other businesses and committed to community events for more exposure.

 

Organization and Management

 

OORadio is a sole-proprietorship business, operated, maintained, and hosted by Priestess Osaremi Lanloke. Priestess Osaremi Ogunleye Lanloke, founder and Host of Omo Oduduwa Radio, was born in Oyotunji African Village in Sheldon, South Carolina to Chief Alagba Ogunleye and Priestess Ayoka Abiomi Lanloke. Her family taught her everything that they could about the customs and traditions of her ancestors. Osaremi is a priestess of Obatala, teacher, speaker, founder, producer and radio host of Omo Oduduwa Radio.

 

By trade, Osaremi has extensive experience in cultural event planning, which includes the Awolowo Festival, Harvest Festival and Ancestral Egungun Conference. In 2002, Osaremi founded The Cultural Exchange, an events planning company which produced the 2004 African Women's Conference, Market Days at Lush Life Cafe and the World AIDS Day event for Kennesaw State University.

 


Osaremi is currently hosting Omo Oduduwa Radio, which she founded in spring 2010. She can be reached at osaremi@hotmail.com.



 

What We Need

 

  • New logo
  • Marketing Plan
  • PO Box
  • We need to get incorporated including all application fees
  • We need for a pro- account on Blogtalkradio to do our shows
  • We need for a fully functioning, professional and interactive website
  • Promotional material (business cards, stationary, fliers, brochures, etc.)

  

What you get:

 

  • Ire (Good Luck) OORadio- Shout out on OORadio shows and Facebook pages 

  • Alafia (Peace) OORadio- Above plus Thank you card 

  • Ayo (Joy) OORadio- Above plus OORadio Mouse Pad

  • Ogbon (Wisdom) OORadio- Above plus OORadio Tee Shirt 

  • Imo (Knowledge) OORadio -Above plus copy of the book, I Hear Olofi’s Song: A Collection of Yoruba Prayers for Egun and Orisa by Ayoka Wiles 

  • Agbada (Strength) OORadio- Above plus CD , Alaako Oso “The Owner of Songs is Eloquent” by Amma McKen

  • Ilera (Good Health) OORadio- Above plus OORadio Tote Bag 


The Impact

 

Omo Oduduwa Radio has been impacting the Yoruba community worldwide over the last 2 years in countries such as the United States, United kingdom, Brazil, Germany, nigeria, Ukraine, Canada, Russia, Venezuela, the Netherlands and more.  

 

We have had such guest including HRM Oba Adejuyigbe Adefunmi II (King of Oyotunji), HRM Alayelusa Oba Al-Marrof Adekunle Magbagbeola (Obalufon), Awise Wande Abimbola (Ifa world spokesperson), Araba Ifayemi Elebuibon (Araba Oshogboland), Chief FAMA, Chief Ayo Salami, Chief Ifabowale Somadhi, Chief Solagbade Poopola, and many others.

 

We have more then 150 shows archived have been listen to over 40,000 times and growing.

  

Other Ways You Can Help OORadio

Share this campaign with family, friends and everyone you know. Also, be sure to share on Facebook, Twitter and Email. Share our story. Share the story of Orisa tradition through having our very own worldwide radio station.

Organization and Management
 
OORadio is a sole-proprietorship business, operated, maintained, and hosted by Priestess Osaremi Lanloke. Priestess Osaremi Ogunleye Lanloke, founder and Host of Omo Oduduwa Radio, was born in Oyotunji African Village in Sheldon, South Carolina to Chief Alagba Ogunleye and Priestess Ayoka Abiomi Lanloke. Her family taught her everything that they could about the customs and traditions of her ancestors. Osaremi is a priestess of Obatala, teacher, speaker, founder, producer and radio host of Omo Oduduwa Radio.
 
By trade, Osaremi has extensive experience in cultural event planning, which includes the Awolowo Festival, Harvest Festival and Ancestral Egungun Conference. In 2002, Osaremi founded The Cultural Exchange, an events planning company which produced the 2004 African Women's Conference, Market Days at Lush Life Cafe and the World AIDS Day event for Kennesaw State University.
 
Osaremi is currently hosting Omo Oduduwa Radio, which she founded in spring 2010. She can be reached at osaremi@hotmail.com.

 
What We Need
 

New logo
Marketing Plan
PO Box
We need to get incorporated including all application fees
We need for a pro- account on Blogtalkradio to do our shows
We need for a fully functioning, professional and interactive website
Promotional material (business cards, stationary, fliers, brochures, etc.)
  
What you get:
 


Ire (Good Luck) OORadio- Shout out on OORadio shows and Facebook pages 


Alafia (Peace) OORadio- Above plus Thank you card 


Ayo (Joy) OORadio- Above plus OORadio Mouse Pad


Ogbon (Wisdom) OORadio- Above plus OORadio Tee Shirt 


Imo (Knowledge) OORadio -Above plus copy of the book, I Hear Olofi’s Song: A Collection of Yoruba Prayers for Egun and Orisa by Ayoka Wiles 



Agbada (Strength) OORadio- Above plus CD , Alaako Oso “The Owner of Songs is Eloquent” by Amma McKen


Ilera (Good Health) OORadio- Above plus OORadio Tote Bag 


The Impact
 
Omo Oduduwa Radio has been impacting the Yoruba community worldwide over the last 2 years in countries such as the United States, United kingdom, Brazil, Germany, nigeria, Ukraine, Canada, Russia, Venezuela, the Netherlands and more.  
 
We have had such guest including HRM Oba Adejuyigbe Adefunmi II (King of Oyotunji), HRM Alayelusa Oba Al-Marrof Adekunle Magbagbeola (Obalufon), Awise Wande Abimbola (Ifa world spokesperson), Araba Ifayemi Elebuibon (Araba Oshogboland), Chief FAMA, Chief Ayo Salami, Chief Ifabowale Somadhi, Chief Solagbade Poopola, and many others.
 
We have more then 150 shows archived have been listen to over 40,000 times and growing.
  
Other Ways You Can Help OORadio
Share this campaign with family, friends and everyone you know. Also, be sure to share on Facebook, Twitter and Email. Share our story. Share the story of Orisa tradition through having our very own worldwide radio station.

story:
The very basic idea: I need to raise money to buy a motorhome to live in. I am homeless now and need something very soon as winter is setting in and I need to live as cheaply as possible.

I have found what i think to be a decent deal on a motorhome!

And YOU can help me get it!

There is a decent looking motorhome up for auction locally. I have gone out and looked it over and it seems to be in decent shape for a 25 year old Motorhome. Looks like it was well cared for and kept up.



The auction closes on the 11th (Tues). Just a couple of days away! I don't want to speculate on what the final bid amount is going to be. It is at $2500 right now. It wouldn't surprize me if that doubles, or more, between now and the end of the auction.

But even if I don't manage to get it together for this one, there always seem to be motorhomes comeing up for sale.

 

Part of the idea is to outfit this thing with solar panels and an extra bank of batteries so I won't have to plug in to any shore power. And even though its got a generator (With only 29 hours on it!) I'd like to use as little non-renewable energy as possible. (Obviously the engine isn't going to be "off the grid"....at least for a while.)

I don't really plan to drive the thing a whole lot. I'll find places to park it in town (I've got a short-list of locations) BUT I do hope to make a few longer road trips in it, and possibly web-cast the adventures along the way.

Aside from the ideas of sustainable energy and off the grid living, I need to live CHEAPLY!

I want to be able to live as cheaply as possible, for a while.


It is getting colder! 

Off The Grid and Mobile!

I am trying to view being homless not as a "curse" or "affliction" but more of an opportunity and motivation to put a few of my ideas about sustainable living to practice, and to the test.

  • My name is Bob Cutler. I am a sound engineer by trade. I have worked in the murky and shadowy world of underground music for decades. This means I have never had a 401K, or much of a savings account, or retirement fund. 
  • My life has taken yet another un-planned for but not entirely unpredictable turn, and I find myself homeless. My basic abstract bottom line here is to raise money to buy myself a cheap, sustainable home.
  • Beyond just putting a thin aluminum barrior between myself and true homelessness, I want to explore and develop methods and technologies for surviving "Off The Grid": Free from financial and technocratic bondage to utility companies and their impact on the environment.

I have a long, sad and frustrating story of what has lead me to this point in my life. I'll bore you with it if you really want to know. But I feel kind of creepy telling my own tale of woe knowing that there are a lot of people with far more painful and pathetic lives out there. The long and the short of it is that until very recently I had been taking care of my elderly dying father. His care in his home became more then I could manage. He is now in a care facility and I am homeless. And being that for the entire time I was caring for him I was unable to work a "real" job, and therefor have saved up no resources of my own.

What is my plan?

Break it down for folks in more detail:

The $25,000 goal I posted here is only a guess. Like anything, the sky is the limit. The main goal is to buy a working motorhome / RV that I can live in. (As well as some sort of rental space to store my stuff that I no longer have a home for)

What do you get out of the deal?
Well, what do you want?

One of my projects will be to have this entire motorhome wired to run on solar and wind energy. As part of that  will be conducting experiments in solar and photovoltaic technology. In short: I'll be creating little "toys" based on some of Tesla's theories. I will reward these to larger donors.

If all else fails, I'll just go rent an apartment in a human ant hill.

The Impact

When the going gets weird.....the weird go mobile!
Things change. Usually at a pace and schedule that we arn't quite ready for or happy with.
 
I'll spare you as much of the long stupid soap opra story as I can and cut to the bottom line:

I need to buy a working motorhome. This is the cheapest and simplest solution I can imagine for my situation for the time being.
 
 
I'm homeless.
And I suddenly have a bunch of legal bills and expenses that I didn't have just a couple of weeks ago.
 
I had been a "home care giver" for my elderly father, living in his home and taking care of him as best I (we) could as he suffers from Parkinsons and Alzhimers, Diabetes and just being old, tired and cantankerous. (And thats the part we love about him!)
 
Cutting out a sad, angry, miserable and embarassing (And very confusing!) story of a chain of events, suffice it to say that Dad's care needs had become something that I (we) could no longer manage in his home.
(And my personal safety and mental and emotional well being have ALSO become "at risk" in that environment, to put it politely)

So, Dad is now in a Hospice Care House where he can get the health care and support that he needs, that we were no longer able to give him at home.
 
In the mean time, as Dad's finances and status of his house gets sorted out. (His house may have to get sold off to cover the costs of his end of life care.....We're not holding our breath for Romney or the Tea party to help out and chip in a few bucks.) I am "between homes".

My plan for now is to buy an RV. A large motorhome type vehical that I can live in. (Or alternately, a camper trailer. But having something self-propelled is MUCH better)
I don't plan on actually driving the thing a whole lot, unless necisary, but I want to be able to move quickly and easily from one place to another.
Remember: You arn't homeless if you are CAMPING! (Or on tour)
 
 
For now this is the simplest, and cheapest lifestyle I can imagine for myself for the next year or so (Or forever!?)

story:
Summer of Solutions

This summer, young leaders are joining forces in 15 cities nation-wide to build the green economy, create community solutions, and show the world what's possible.


Summer of Solutions Oakland is made of team of 25 brilliant and activated young leaders, ages 18-30, from diverse racial, geographic, socio-economic backgrounds. We will be investing a total of 8000+ hours towards implementing local, innovative, community-based solutions in Oakland this summer. 

 

We will use ingenuity, passion, and creativity to address issues related to food justice, clean energy technology, community resilience, and story telling. This will be a transformative community effort in solidarity with hundreds of Fruitvale and Oakland citizens, local businesses, thought leaders and community partners.

 

Can you donate $25, $250, or $500 to support young leaders build the green economy? 

 

Our Story

All across the planet, a unique and powerful generation is coming of age. A convergence of crises – poverty, inequality, economic instability, climate disruption, ecological unraveling – are threatening human civilization as a whole.

At the very same time, a groundswell of consciousness and social change is emerging within our generation. From our schools to our communities to the halls of power we are taking action like never before. Across cultures and generations, we are forming a planet-wide “Movement of movements” including every issue, approach, and sector of society that is remaking our world.

Our generation’s calling is clear: we must take bold action to transform the systems that no longer serve us, and create a peaceful, just, sustainable world that works for all.

 

Why Oakland?

Our program will be located in the Fruitvale neighborhood of Oakland, California.  Fruitvale hosts Oakland’s largest Latino population, comprising 49.5% of Fruitvale’s total population. Oakland struggles with many issues including rapid unemployment, widespread poverty, and an elevated rate of violent crime.  Oakland’s poverty rate is 17.2%. (City-Data.com, 2009)


Summer of Solutions Oakland will bring together a group of passionate youth and community members to improve the economic conditions and human well-being of residents of Fruitvale, as well as develop replicable models for community sustainability.

Theory of Change

In Summer of Solutions Oakland 2011 we will engage four tracks: Food Justice, Clean Energy, Thriving Communities, and Transformational Media & Story. 

Solutionaries will use their creativity, talents, and skills to create self-sustaining and replicable projects related to the tracks.  Summer of Solutions provides participants with training, mentorship, and support to make their projects successful. We partner with local organizations to learn from and support the work that is already happening.

We begin with a strong commitment to equality and justice. We recognize that many communities have been "spoken for" instead of "listened to". In order to truly create global transformation we must begin by addressing root causes of the problems. We do this by engaging in community visioning, and integrating anti-oppression principals and practices in our trainings, projects, and program planning and development.

What We Need & What You Get

Through our grassroots fundraising campaign, we aim to raise a total of $10,000 to support young leaders with the resources they need to be part of the program. Here’s where your donation will make an impact:

  • $4000: Need-based stipends for young Solutionaries

  • $3000: Food for program participants

  • $2000: Housing and Logistical Costs

  • $550: Program Materials and Training Supplies (flip charts, markers, binders, flash drivers, A/V equipment rentals, etc.)

  • $450: Grand Aspirations National Fundraising Goal


We want you to be 100% confident that your donation will result in tangible social change in the communities we work with. To ensure this, our team will:

  • Send you monthly updates on our progress via email

  • Give you a comprehensive report highlighting each element of our program at the end of the summer

  • Maintain a frequently-updated blog that will feature stories from program participants, updates on our projects, and reflections on our community-building process throughout the summer


We are also pursuing other sources of funding through grants and fellowships. However, we know the most meaningful and reliable way to generate resources for the program is through you, the grassroots. We want to extend our gratitude for your generous support by offering unique perks for donations!

Other Ways YOU Can Be Solutionary

 
Summer of Solutions Oakland is powered by YOU, and here are other ways you can help aside from donating: 
 

  • Facebook: Use the power of social networking to help us spread the word about SoS - Oakland. Post the link to this page on your wall and on your status, and post it on friends’ walls, too! 

  • Twitter: Tweet the link to this site!

  • Email: Hit up your contact list with an email about SoS Oakland and why you chose to donate. Make sure to include the link to this page, and let your contacts know to forward it along to their networks as well.

  • Word of Mouth: One of the most powerful drivers of social action is through in person dialogue. Start a conversation with your friends, family, and co-workers about what we’re up to in Oakland! Then, you can direct them to this website, and they can pass with word on to others.

  • Call: If you can’t talk to your friends and family in person, give them a ring: they’d love to hear from you, and while you’re catching up you can let them know about SoS Oakland and how to support our program.

Twitter: Tweet the link to this site!


Email: Hit up your contact list with an email about SoS Oakland and why you chose to donate. Make sure to include the link to this page, and let your contacts know to forward it along to their networks as well.


Word of Mouth: One of the most powerful drivers of social action is through in person dialogue. Start a conversation with your friends, family, and co-workers about what we’re up to in Oakland! Then, you can direct them to this website, and they can pass with word on to others.

story:
Tony and Shane decided to open a restaurant.  Not just any restaurant, however, as they decided they would serve amazing street food, inspired by Tony's time in Asia and Shane's constant impulse to chase food trucks through LA as if he were still eight years old chasing the ice cream man.  The menu grew, then grew and grew and grew.  

Then two amazing chefs Andy Richards and Zachary Morrison came along.  The menu became a living, breathing entity and out of respect for simple, delicious food we all crave to eat every day, all agreed that it would be necessary to reconstruct the menu in such a manner that all components of each dish were sourced ethically. Organic vegetables? You got it. Sustainable ingredients? Yep.  Local, farm-raised chicken, beef, and fish, you'll have it here.  There has been a resurgence of farming in and around Redlands lately, and we think there is nothing cooler than composing our dishes with fresh produce that creates jobs and keeps money in our local economy.

This task has proven to be monumental and we are up to the challenge! This is where YOU come in. All of us at Food & Beer would like your help in making this project a reality. By donating, you can not only pocket some meaningful karmic rewards, but also some tangible ones! All money raised in this endeavor will go towards partnering with local providers to supply Food & Beer with grass fed, pen/cage free, and organic proteins and produce. If you choose to donate, be assured that your money will stay in our community of Redlands with dividends being paid back on your plate.

story:
Executive Summary:

Thomas F. La Vecchia, MBA aka The Sales Expert.  He is the Author of the best selling title The X Factor Selling System and has sold over $100 million dollars of goods/services over his 20 year corporate career.  He has turned around dozens of sales teams, business and lead 100s of sale professionals.

The Rainmaker will document his efforts on saving businesses that are on the brink of financial ruin.

We will document his adventures and turn them into a show or documentary

What We Need & What You Get

The monies will go to:

  • Pre-production: scouting, hiring and obtaining equipment
  • Production: Filming in and around NYC
  • Post-Production - Professional Editing and Scoring

Impact

The businesses that will be visited during The Rainmaker are real as many have their life savings on the line.  Tom and his team will evaluate the situatiion, put together an immediate plan for saving the business.  Once the business is stabilized Tom will provide the plan for "breakout" thats when the business will hit "critical mass" and achieve greatness.

Other Ways You Can Help

We kindly ask for an investment at any level, but also pass the word to family, friends and colleagues as this is truly going to be a special event.

story:
Hi. My name is Kylee Lane and I am the CEO and creative force behind LuxuryLaneSoap.com. I have been fortunate enough to build and grow my company from very small beginnings, almost ten years ago with no initial funding and I have reached a bridge I can not cross without your help.

It is time for me to expand. I have the space and I have the muscle to build the studio of my dreams, but I simply do not have the money. My available area is raw and in need of some serious restoration. With your help, I will be able to purchase the materials I need to build the future of my company.

What We Need & What You Get

The area we are using is a ballroom on top of a 1917 Georgian revival style home in Sheldon, IA. In the 1940's, the entire 1,000 square foot area was converted into an apartment. In 2013, my family and I began tearing down walls to completely renovate this space and give it new life as The Lane Laboratory. This will be a place to passionately create with the tools needed to continue producing products you love.

Even if we don't reach our goal, every dollar raised helps buy materials!

So here is what we need and where the money will go:

-Floor repair. 1134 square feet of flooring

-Full electrical. Lights including wiring, outlets and junction boxes

-Tear down apartment walls and repair outside walls. Plaster, taping mud and paint

-Window replacements and frame repair

-Lumber for building tables, shelving and work stations

-New pipes/plumbing. Ugh. Plumbing...

-Equipment rental and waste removal services

-Restocking raw materials and production costs

We will be doing all of the labor ourselves to keep costs down and the more we can raise, the more we can do! If you have a service you would like to donate, please let us know!

We anticipate documenting all of this! So you can look forward to online tutorials and/or blog posts of our being awesome. (We actually love doing this stuff. See some of our work here and here.)

Mega Bonus! If you guys rock my world, anything over $5,000 goes into:
- Product line expansion!

- Computer hardware and/or software update!

- A screen printer. No more flaking labels!

- Hiring and training a customer service team with on-site help!

But we will talk more about those goals later...

The Impact

Every. Single. Dollar. Helps. 

Even from a single dollar collected, every last donation will go towards the tools I need. I will complete this studio and you have the power to ensure it happens before I am 200 years old.

As a contributor, not only are you helping breathe life back into a nearly 100-year old piece of history, you are helping me prove that this can be done. I have been talking about this expansion for years and it is time to make it happen. As a small business, I do not have to sell out for growth and profit and I CAN continue setting my own terms.

Other Ways You Can Help

Check out LuxuryLaneSoap.com as I clear out inventory for the rebuild! 

Even if you can't monetarily contribute, please consider spreading the word about my campaign by sharing and posting links all over the place. <3
story_txt:
Hi.
My name is Kylee
Lane and
I am the CEO and creative force behind LuxuryLaneSoap.com.
I have been fortunate enough to build and grow my company from very
small beginnings, almost ten years ago with no initial funding and I
have reached a bridge I can not cross without your help.It is time for me to expand. I have the space and I have the muscle to build the studio of my dreams, but I simply do not have the money. My available area is raw and in need of some serious restoration. With your help, I will be able to purchase the materials I need to build the future of my company.What
We Need & What You GetThe
area we are using is a ballroom on top of a 1917 Georgian revival
style home in Sheldon, IA. In the 1940's, the entire 1,000
square foot area was converted into an apartment. In 2013, my family
and I began tearing down walls to completely renovate this
space and give it new life as The Lane Laboratory. This will be a
place to passionately create with the tools needed to continue
producing products you love.Even
if we don't reach our goal, every dollar raised helps buy materials!

So
here is what we need and where the money will go:

-Floor
repair. 1134 square feet of flooring

-Full
electrical. Lights including wiring, outlets and junction boxes

-Tear
down apartment walls and repair outside walls. Plaster, taping mud
and paint

-Window
replacements and frame repair

-Lumber
for building tables, shelving and work stations

-New
pipes/plumbing. Ugh. Plumbing...

-Equipment
rental and waste removal services

-Restocking
raw materials and production costsWe will be doing all of the labor ourselves to keep costs down and the more we can raise, the more we can do! If you have a service you would like to donate, please let us know!We anticipate documenting all of this! So you can look forward to online tutorials and/or blog posts of our being awesome. if you can't monetarily contribute, please consider spreading the

place. <3

story:
A postgraduate in International Social Welfare and Social Policy from Anglia Ruskin University, Cambridge, United Kingdom currently working as Head of Operations for a social business called Pollinate Energy in Bangalore, India. Pollinate Energy is an Australian social business working with 470 slum communities in Bangalore providing access to clean energy solutions.

Spending time in these urban slum communities I have realized that the level of menstrual hygiene is really low among the women. I have come across situations where women use ash, mud, plastic, leaves and dirty rag pieces of cloth during their menstrual phases, while I was intrigued and conducted a survey with 250 in the lower income groups, including women from urban slums, girls from government schools and women from factories ,which bought forth an important issue which can help towards the solution of this crisis. Hitherto it was believed that, just a lack of affordability was the major factor in non-usage of sanitary napkins in lower middle class urban society & rural areas of India. But the study indicates that lack of awareness and knowledge are also major contributors to non-usage. 

There are only a few organisations working towards this issue, but their efforts are chiefly concentrated on extremely marginalized rural populations. A colossal section of the female demographic with very low income live in and around cities like Bangalore is neglected, to say the least. There is a serious need for improving the menstrual hygiene for women and girls in these urban slum communities and lower middle income society.

So here I am with Sahana P Bhat venturing into Sukhibhava ,a social enterprise based in Bangalore, India. Sukhibhava aims to tackle contributing factors to gender inequality through provision of products and education that enable and empower women. Menstrual hygiene management is one of those factors and it is unfairly felt by the under privileged and urban poor. Sukhibhava will hold education sessions and sell menstrual hygiene products to urban poor women who previously did not have access due to economic or awareness factors.  A micro distribution business model has been developed where local entrepreneurial women will distribute and sell products. 

Sukhibhava operates on the premise of full life cycle products. From awareness to disposal,this refers to both to concern for the environmental impact of the product as well as aiming to take the journey towards the adoption of new products and services with the customers it deals with. Products that Sukhibhava is interested in are often not easy products to take up. Being there for the customer means ensuring the smoothest uptake. Continued support is important for Sukhibhava to ensure it is making the most impact in the most responsible way. 

After two months of pilot, here we are trying to upscale our operations with three micro entrepreneurs who will be educating and providing the menstrual hygiene products to women in lower income groups. 

This Indiegogo campaign is raising funds to incubate and setup the businesses of three micro entrepreneurs who will be working in three different regions of Bangalore reaching hundreds of thousands of women in the bottom of the pyramid.

100% of your donation will go towards funding our on the ground operations.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, 

My name is Budd Kuyper and I am the founder/CEO of The Anchor House; a pretty new nonprofit organization that has its sights set on ending homelessness.  First in N.E. Ohio, then nationally and then globally.  I have personally been on the streets more than once in my life.  While there I struggled to keep personal hygiene up, to eat daily and keep from falling into the common traps of stealing or panhandling to survive.  I struggled with finding he resources I needed to get back on my feet.  But thanks to God, caring individuals and organizations and my own perseverance I was able to reenter society.  I want to make it a little easier for others that are going through what I went through and worse.  I have personally been funding all of our activities to this point and it is putting a serious strain on my financial resources (as a minimum wage cook).  Gaining our 501(c)(3) status will allow us the opportunity to receive more donations both monetary and inventory.  We have a donor right now who is willing to donate us a building with a market value of over 100k.  This property produces a monthly revenue of over $1,400 a month!  This revenue by its self will allow us to be self sufficient and increase our sack lunches from 250 monthly to 250 WEEKLY! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need 850$ to file our 1023 (501(c)(3)) with the internal revenue service.  The other $76.50 is the 4% indiegogo charges along with 5% to cover the cost of the paypal and credit card processing that indiegogo imposes.  If we fall short of raising 850$, the funds that we DO raise will go into our bank account until the full 850$ is raised.  

For anyone donating $10 - $19 They will receive a hand crafted beaded bracelet that reads "END HOMELESSNESS" each bracelet is made with love by a volunteer and has a charm indicating so. (With permission, we would also like to mention your name on our website)

For anyone donating $20 - $39 they will receive a silicone red, white, and blue swirl wristband that reads "BOUNCE BACK" to represent the fact that they have helped the Anchor House help people BOUNCE BACK from Life's setbacks.  (With permission, we would also like to mention your name on our website)

For anyone donating $50 - $74 they will receive an Anchor House "BOUNCE BACK" T-shirt in the size of their choice.  Shirts are 100% pre-shrunk cotton.  Black Logo screen printed on White T's.  (With permission, we would also like to mention your name on our website)

For anyone donating $75 - $149 They will receive ALL of the above and have the option of having their (or their company/organizations) picture placed on our website  with a sincere thank you for one quarter (3 months)

For anyone donating $150+ They will receive ALL of the above but remain on our website as a featured donor for a full calender year.

The Impact

The Anchor House currently helps out local homeless shelters by dropping off some of our sack lunches to them for their residents as well as distributing them to individuals we see on the streets during our (currently monthly) outreaches.  We have increased from 100 sack lunches to 250 sack lunches already and want to grow from monthly outreaches to weekly outreaches.  Doing the numbers that increases from 250 sack lunches to 1,000 sack lunches a month!  All of our lunches are include a ham or turkey sandwich, an individual bag of chips a snack (currently individual packages of fruit snacks) and a 16.9 oz bottle of water.  Receiving our 501(c)(3) will give us the opportunity to receive donations of bottled water, bread, snacks, juices and more.  It will also offer us the opportunity to accept clothing donations to be able to distribute to those in need as well.  It is highly conceivable that after getting our 501(c)(3) we could increase to WAY MORE than 1,000 sack lunches a month purely from the food/drink donations we will be eligible to receive.  It will also give donors  the opportunity to write off any physical or monetary donations made to us, making donating a more attractive option.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • You can help us in other ways, LIKE our FaceBook page 
  • www.facebook.com/anchorhouse and share it with your friends list.
  • Contact us to donate bottled water or other items.  Before you throw away that old blanket this summer, consider donating it to us so that we can give it to an individual who is living on the streets this winter.
  • Help us get this word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

You can help us in other ways, LIKE our FaceBook page 

www.facebook.com/anchorhouse and share it with your friends list.
Contact us to donate bottled water or other items.  Before you throw away that old blanket this summer, consider donating it to us so that we can give it to an individual who is living on the streets this winter.
Help us get this word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Our community takes a stand against the inefficient status quo. With technology advancing exponentially and worldwide connectivity at its highest, we should no longer live as a species that can't provide for each other. The evidence shows we are at a critical time in our story on Earth. Depleting earth's finite resources, economic downturns and environmental damage are just a few of the problems we face as a species. If we can't care for each other, how do we expect to solve all the other issues that humanity faces?

WaterBomb's aim is to create, organize and curate an event of art, music, fashion and dance to raise awareness, along with monetary relief for the pressing water crisis today. We are working with clean water initiative, Generosity water, to help people in underprivileged communities attain access to clean water. WaterBomb has taken part in two projects in Cambodia and one in Haiti through partnerships with charity: water and Generosity Water. More on our website here.

Join us on April 26, to create positive impact in the lives of people who need it the most. 

WATERBOMB:2014 LINEUP


The Movement Lifestyle, Soulection, KRNFX, Jeni Suk, Dumbfoundead, DJ ZO, EOM, Anderson Paak & the Free Nationals, Platinum Standard, Panthers&Hippies, Illest, Johnny Cupcakes, Loud-Mouse, Love Nail Tree, LACmovement, MOGL, Timeless, MNETamerica, ConnectDTLA, Ninja Sox, Blank Booth, Vape&Juice, And more...

Get your limited pre-sale tickets now via indiegogo! (Ends 4/24 11:59pm PST)

ENTRY WILL BE $20 AT THE DOOR
333 S Boylston St. Los Angeles, CA 90017
7pm - 2am (Performances start at 8pm)
21+ event

ATTENDEES WEARING WATERBOMBER TANKS WILL GET IN FREE!

- 

If you cannot make a financial contribution at the moment, we understand! There are still other ways you can help. Please share this campaign with your friends!

Questions? Comments? Suggestions? Email us at info@WaterBomb.org We would love to hear from you!


www.waterbomb.org

story:
Greetings Prospective Donor:

My name is Tracy Arnold. I am a community developer and the founder of Arnold Place, a 501c.3, non-profit organization based in Prince Georges County, Maryland (suburbs of Washington, D.C).  Currently, we are in the process of acquiring a 16,400 square foot facility to serve as a transitional shelter for 24 young women (ages 14-22) who may be homeless; pregnant and/or diagnosed with HIV/AIDs.  In addition to the residential facility, Arnold Place hopes to purchase an adjacent 8,000 square foot building to provide supportive services to the residents such as: Occupational Skills Training;  Computer Skills; Financial Literacy and other supportive services to young women in transition.  Arnold Place will be a “place of Serenity, Comfort, Transformation and Hope”. We need your financial support to help make this much needed facility a reality for homeless young women and pregnant teens in the D.C., Maryland metropolitan area.

Meet Arnold Place’s Founder—Ms. Tracy Arnold:

Born in Washington, DC, I spent most of my youth in the nearby Maryland suburb of Prince Georges County. As a result, I am very familiar with many of the issues and concerns of young people in the community.  Upon completing my high school education, I worked in the federal government in a number of capacities. However, I have always had a passion for helping those in need. So, in 1998, I made a decision to go into the mortgage profession as a Mortgage Originator.  In only two years, it was evident that I had found my niche. I became the top producer for an office of more than 20 loan officers; while managing 10 other loan originators at the same time. I served in that position for 4 years, learning as much as I could about the mortgage business. Then in 2005, I opened my own, independent  mortgage brokerage company-- Mortgage Consultants for Life, Inc.  (MCL).

Since its inception, MCL has helped hundreds of families purchase their first home; or refinance their home totaling approximately $100,000,000 in loan amounts with the numbers increasing monthly.  However, during the recession, the mortgage business took a downward spiral, which basically cost me everything—my business, my home, my hopes and dreams.  It has not been easy, but I was able to start over. Meanwhile, I have also been given an assignment to “Help Others”, especially young girls and women who are experiencing homelessness; teen pregnancy; or diagnosed with HIV/AIDs. 

Having had some turbulent teenage years as a runaway, I know firsthand how being homeless can lead young women down the wrong path in life, if they do not have the guidance and support needed.  I also know that just because you may make some bad choices, it does not mean that you cannot turn your life around and do something positive.   Arnold Place, will be a place of serenity that young women can come to live for a defined period of time; find hope and be given a chance to transform their lives.

My personal motto is: “No One Can Do Everything, but Everybody Can Do Something.”  I have taken my pain and turned it into a passion to help young women by building Arnold Place.  I truly hope that my story will move you to donate to this very worthwhile initiative.

Why Give to Arnold Place:

By donating to Arnold Place, you will help build “a place of Serenity, Hope and Transformation” for young, homeless, women (ages 14-22) in the metropolitan .D.C. area.  Your donation will not only provide young women a place to live while their lives are in transition, but you will also provide them an opportunity to receive counseling, education, life skills and other beneficial training.  Using a customized six month curriculum, each resident will receive the personal development, guidance and assistance needed to help transition their lives from homelessness to independence.

How You Can Help:

Arnold Place is asking for your monetary donation to support our building renovation efforts.  No donation is too small or too large!  With a minimum donation of just $10.00, you can help make an impact.  Of course, the more you give, the greater impact your donation will have on furthering  Arnold Place’s  building renovation efforts.

We recognize the state of the economy today may inhibit some people who want to help support a worthy cause financially.  So, we also have established other grassroots fundraising efforts such as: our Shoe Donation and Clothing Donation projects.

Additionally, we have a goal to collect at least 1 million pairs of shoes (worn or new); and 1 million pounds of clothing (men, women and children). All shoes and clothing will be recycled and a monetary donation made back to Arnold Place, a 501c.3, charitable organization.

We ask that you pass the word to others you know or may have in your contact list. By spreading the word about  Arnold Place, you continue to help us meet  our renovation efforts.  In fact, by telling just one more person, you will helps us reach someone else who can contribute to Arnold Place’s building renovation.  With your help, we hope to meet our goal; and open the doors to Arnold Place in April, 2015. 

Thank you in advance for your support.

FAQ

How can I donate my shoes and clothes?

Arnold Place will come and pick your shoes up from your home or place of employment.  All you have to do is contact our offices and we will schedule a pick up at your convenience.

Are my donations tax deductible?

Yes all donations with an average retail or monetary donation of $10 or more is tax deductible.

How are the women selected to live in the home?

Arnold Place will except women in need from current shelters who can no longer meet the needs of the women, from government agencies and hospitals.

What are the qualifications to live in the home?

The resident must be willing to adhere to all of the rules and regulations of the home.  The resident must also be willing to participate in a minimum 6 month program, for some the program may be longer depending on the need.

My personal motto is: “No One Can Do Everything, but Everybody Can
Do Something.”  I have taken my pain and turned it
into a passion to help young women by building Arnold Place.  I truly hope that my story will move you to
donate to this very worthwhile initiative.
Why
Give to Arnold Place:
By donating to Arnold Place, you will help build “a place of Serenity, Hope and
Transformation” for young, homeless, women (ages 14-22) in the metropolitan
.D.C. area.  Your donation will not only
provide young women a place to live while their lives are in transition, but
you will also provide them an opportunity to receive counseling, education,
life skills and other beneficial training. 
Using a customized six month curriculum, each resident will receive the
personal development, guidance and assistance needed to help transition their
lives from homelessness to independence.
How
You Can Help:
Arnold Place is asking for your monetary donation to support our
building renovation efforts.  No donation
is too small or too large!  With a
minimum donation of just $10.00, you can help make an impact.  Of course, the more you give, the greater impact your donation
will have on furthering  Arnold Place’s  building renovation efforts.
We recognize the state of the economy today may inhibit some people who want
to help support a worthy cause financially.  So, we also have established other grassroots
fundraising efforts such as: our Shoe Donation and Clothing Donation projects.
Additionally,
we have a goal to collect at least 1 million pairs of shoes (worn or new); and 1 million pounds of clothing (men, women and children). All shoes and clothing will be recycled and a
monetary donation made back to Arnold Place, a 501c.3, charitable organization.
We ask that you pass the word to others you know or may have
in your contact list. By spreading the word about  Arnold Place, you continue to help
us meet  our renovation efforts.  In fact, by telling just one more person, you
will helps us reach someone else who can contribute to Arnold Place’s building
renovation.  With your help, we hope to meet our goal; and open the
doors to Arnold Place in April, 2015.  
Thank you in advance for your support.

FAQ
How can I donate my
shoes and clothes?
Arnold Place will come and pick your shoes up from your home
or place of employment.  All you have to
do is contact our offices and we will schedule a pick up at your convenience.
Are my donations tax
deductible?
Yes all donations with an average retail or monetary
donation of $10 or more is tax deductible.
How are the women
selected to live in the home?
Arnold Place will except women in need from current shelters
who can no longer meet the needs of the women, from government agencies and
hospitals.
What are the
qualifications to live in the home?
The resident must be willing to adhere to all of the rules
and regulations of the home.  The
resident must also be willing to participate in a minimum 6 month program, for
some the program may be longer depending on the need.

story:
Our Girls, Our Vision

hers (honoring and empowering our resilient sisters) is a community program that works with foster youth girls to give them the transformative knowledge, leadership training, and supportive community to build the life of her dreams. We work with girls ages 15-19 in foster care throughout the year and the funds raised from this campaign will support the summer retreat in July. We started hers after spending the past year working with foster youth in Mississippi and realizing there was no space for foster girls to discuss the issues that matter to them.  "We're not bad kids", they would say, We've just had bad things happen to us". These youth needed an outlet to speak out and become empowered.  Most of the time when people hear Mississippi and any statistic associated with youth, foster teens are consistently in last place.  BUT these girls are NOT statistics.  They are amazing, intelligent, creative, resilient young women who have had bad things happen to them. The only thing they suffer from is a lack of resources, opportunity, and support.  

That's why we created hers; a leadership community. At hers we insist on a world where every young woman has the resources and opportunities to create the life she envisions for her self, her family, and her community. hers is a place for these young women to have a supportive community, learn about building healthy relationships with herself and those around her, and gain the skills she needs to make empowered decisions about her body and her future. While many have looked at Mississippi as the bottom or the finish line for girls empowerment, we know that these girls hold endless power to change their lives and the communities around them.

At the summer retreat, we will use a co-building education model that is used in other parts of the country to empower youth and build a relevant curriculum for specific populations. We will focus on sex education, building healthy relationships, racial equity, physical education, and mindfulness training. Support and join our movement to empower girls!

Our Girls Matter!

While we know our girls are not statistics, we understand the systemic barriers that prevent them from actualizing their full potential.  hers is facing these barriers head on! Our girls will no longer be represented by these numbers. 

Impact

We are excited about bringing a  variety of  services, trainings, and resources to our girls.  We are focusing on addressing the entire girl: her spirit, her mind, her body, her relationships, and her community.  Check out our activities and trainings!

Group Activities: Mindful Yoga, Zumba, Team Building, and Conflict Resolution

Trainings: Sex Education, Building Healthy Relationships, Healthy Behaviors, Racial Equity, Advocacy


Your Support, Our Movement

Your donations support meals, retreat lodging, group activities, and trainings! Help us build a movement to empower our girls.  Join our movement!

story:
OUR KIDS WANT TO LEARN ABOUT GARDENING WHILE GROWING 100's OF POUNDS OF VEGETABLES TO DONATE TO THE LOCAL FOOD PANTRY.
     WE HAVE THE LAND.
     WE HAVE THE VOLUNTEERS.
     YOU  HAVE THE POWER TO FINANCE THE SUPPLIES THEY NEED TO DO IT.

     When I learned that our community garden couldn't find volunteers or funds to support the Children's Garden, I knew we had to do something about that.
     I contacted area groups asking them to donate their time and energy to help me plant, maintain, and harvest a large garden full of vegetables.  The Daisy, Brownie, and Girl Scouts along with Cub, Boy, and Eagle Scouts have responded to the Call to Action.  They will be volunteering their time and ambition alongside Master Gardeners and other volunteers, to start the seeds, transplant into garden beds, water/weed/and maintain the gardens all Spring and Summer long until harvest.
     Now we need YOU, the Community, to stand up and support our children in their goals by providing the materials and supplies needed to reach their goals!

     We are setting a crowdfunding goal of $500 to cover the cost of our required supplies.
                               *Organic Vegetable Seeds........................$100
                           *3 Yds Dairy Doo Compost.......................$150-200
                           *Garden gloves/tools................................$100
                           *RubberMaid Garden Storage Shed.........$150-200

     This project has multiple ambitions!! 
     *Educating new gardeners and mentoring youth to take an active role in the community.  
     *Engaging children in the movement for a healthy, local, and thriving food system.
     *Fostering the virtue of Charity by donating our harvests to local Food Pantries and Needy Families in our area.

     Our greatest challenges have been overcome already!!!  We have a beautiful garden space within which to grow!  We have eager volunteers and excited children ready to make this a fun, educational, and productive project.
     Now it rests in your hands. 
     Show our kids that if they step up, others will too.
     Donate now to make a difference in our Community
    
     If you cannot donate funds, donate your time; Share our vision with your family and friends by sharing this IndieGoGo campaign.  Help us spread the word!

story:
Last night a very amazing woman passed away. We are looking for any size donations to help pay for her funeral as we all know they can be very costly. Please help her children and family give her the funeral she deserves. We only have about 3 days to do this. Any help will be greatly appreciated.

Sunday the 19th Lydia had troubles breathing and after she got to the hospital she then had gone into cardiac arrest, prompting nurses to do CPR for a few minutes, she lost too much oxygen to the brain during that time. There was some brain activity, but there had been some damage already done. Doctors said she kept having seizures every few minutes because of this. They tried multiple medications to try and stop the seizures, but nothing was working. They then said it was not looking good and that she may NEVER wake up from this. After being in the hospital in a coma for a week, the seizures didnt stop. Lydia was in a coma. Her children made the hardest decision of their lives to remove her from life support. Lydia passed away August 26th at 10:04pm EST.

Lydia had a good long hard fight with health problems. She was a strong willed woman and fought through everything. This was just too much for her to handle. We all love her and will miss her very much and feel she should have a proper burial.

Thank you all for any donations and support we may get.

story:
Short Summary

Last summer, the Snohomish Boys & Girls Club had a couple of very remarkable and impactful experiences. First, a local Girl Scout troop built 2 beautiful raised vegetable gardens for our kids to plant and maintain. Luckily, they are in excellant condition and can be used for many years. Another cool experience was taking the kids to a blueberry farm and watching their excitment in picking the berries and even more so in taking them home and sharing with their families. It was neat to hear about what they planned to make with them. It is really hard to believe that most kids do not know where their food comes from and how many have not experienced gardening and farming.

The idea for this project stemmed from a great event last year. The Snohomish Farmers Market held a one day "Kids Day at the Market". During that day, local kids could set up tables at the Farmers Market and sell items that they had made. We signed up for a table and got busy creating! We decided to use recycled bottles to make "stained glass" vases and candle holders. They turned out beautiful and were a hit with shoppers. However, that was not the best part. The best part was watching the crafters sell the vases and how happy it made them to talk to people about how they had made them. After that day, the kids set the table up at the Boys & Girls Club and kept selling items for many days.

Through this project, we will set up a weekly "City Kids County Marketplace" once a week on the large lawn in front of our Club. We plan to bringin local artists to teach the kids marketable skills such as soap making, candle dipping, baking, jewelry making, and other forms of art. Through the market, they will also learn business skills such as marketing, promotions, setting up displays, money, and much more.

With the money raised in this campaign, we will purchase supplies, bring in teachers, promote the market, and purchase items such as tables and tents. We will also use the funds to maintain our garden and purchase seeds.

As a Boys & Girls Club project, this fits perfectly into our "Formula For Impact" and our priority outcomes of Healthy Lifestyles, Good Character and Citizenship, and Academic Success. Through this High Yield Learning Activity, all outcome areas are achieved.

story:
About the Fuzzy Bee: 

Hello! My name is Marisa Woods and I am the proud owner of The Fuzzy Bee, a handmade card and illustration company. 

I started The Fuzzy Bee in 2011 as a way to pursue and keep up with my degree in Studio Art. I have always been an artist. Through The Fuzzy Bee, I have been able to pursue my lifelong dream of making and producing my work. 

In the past two years I have sold my work, gained sales experience, created and worked with my online etsy shop, and taken an online class in handmade business. I am finally ready to make The Fuzzy Bee a reality and take this business to the next level. I am starting this fundraising campaign for key supplies and capital to launch The Fuzzy Bee and fall line in 2013. 

This is where you, my super fans, come in! 

 

 

What I Need and Some Real Fuzzy Perks: 

I have spent a while figuring out what I need to make this business efficient on it's own, right from the start. I need some key materials and initial capital to make this possible!

1) The Mac- Although my current mac is awesome and we are best friends, The Fuzzy Bee is in desperate need of an art specific computer. The Mac is the brains of the whole operation, as I draw most of my images on a drawing tablet on photoshop. The total cost of the Mac is $1,500. 

2) The Printer- I have been printing my items with some help from friends and family and am ready to take on the job myself! A way to print my work is important as The Fuzzy Bee is first launching. Cost? $1000

3) The Camera- I use a small point and shoot right now but if I have learned anything from etsy and online sales, it is that photos of your work are everything! The camera cost- $900

4) Materials and Paper- The rest of the funds are going towards my spring line, shipping costs, and capital for marketing. What does that mean? That includes; paper, ink, envelopes, more paper, shipping envelopes, stamps, packaging design, and yes, MORE PAPER! $1,700

All donations to The Fuzzy Bee come with perks! If you go to the right hand side bar you can select what donation level you would like!

Make sure to watch the video above as it will also explain more about my company and some fuzzy perks. You can head over to the "Gallery" and take a look at some of my current cards for the spring!  

Other Ways You Can Help and How to Get in Touch: 

If you cannot donate funds don't worry! You can help me out in the following ways:

1) Join my mailing list! Go to thefuzzybee.com to join or email me and I can add you. 

2) Like me on facebook! Join my page and share the awesome. 

3) Head over to my etsy shop and say HELLO or I don't know...buy a card!

And that’s all there is to it.
